Title: Head-to-Knee Pose
Alt Text: How to do Head-to-Knee Pose Yoga
Short Description: Head-to-Knee Pose (Janu Sirsasana) is a seated forward bend with one leg extended, and one leg bent out to the side. The pose stretches the hamstrings, groins, and spine and enhances flexibility in the hips and lower back.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Head-to-Knee Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5fr6525467","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by sitting on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you (staff pose).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c860b25469","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend your right knee and bring the sole of your right foot to rest against the inside of your left thigh. Your right knee should point out to the side.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"11zxe25471","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Keep your left leg firmly pressed into the ground, engaging the quadriceps and flexing your left foot.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"23i1l25473","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Sit up tall, lengthening your spine, and take a deep breath in.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9uh1p25475","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Exhale and begin to hinge at your hips, leading with your chest. Keep your back straight as you fold forward over your left leg.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y279325477","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Reach your arms forward and then down, aiming to grab your left foot with both hands. If you can't reach your foot, you can hold onto your calf or use a yoga strap around your foot.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"nrqt525479","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. As you fold forward, maintain the length in your spine. Imagine your belly button moving toward your left thigh.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"708d525481","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Relax your shoulders away from your ears and allow your head and neck to soften.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lq8fn25483","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Breathe deeply and hold the pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, or longer if comfortable.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7zs6325485","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. To come out of the pose, inhale and slowly lift your torso back up, keeping your back straight.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fxnn125487","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Extend both legs out in front of you again and shake them out to release any tension.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qjf9125489","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Repeat the same steps on the other side, bending your left knee and bringing the sole of your left foot to rest against your right inner thigh.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:15:30.969Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:15:30.969Z","id":"a5967fa2-cd4e-4ed5-bceb-a40a1755482f"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"blglw27160","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"h99sx28488","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6dfhc28489","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e85cf28469","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Knee injuries:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have a knee injury or pain in the knee of the bent leg, avoid or modify this pose. Putting pressure on a compromised knee may exacerbate the injury.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jdxon28492","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"tarle27164","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hamstring injuries:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Individuals with severe hamstring injuries should be cautious as this pose involves stretching the hamstrings. Perform the pose gently and avoid overstretching.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6z6qg28495","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dsep027168","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Sciatica:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Avoid this pose if you have sciatica or any condition that causes shooting pain down the back of the legs, as it can aggravate the sciatic nerve.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hyrrp28498","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3tcbi27172","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lower back issues:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have a herniated disc or lower back pain, be careful with this pose. Folding forward may strain the lower back. Consider using props and bending the extended knee slightly to protect the lower back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5tnac28501","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"tsevo27176","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High blood pressure or glaucoma:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" For those with high blood pressure or glaucoma, folding forward can increase intraocular pressure. It's best to avoid or modify this pose by keeping the head elevated.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"uo4on28504","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n2h7l27180","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Pregnant women should avoid deep forward bends like Janu Sirsasana, especially as the belly grows. Instead, practice more gentle poses suitable for pregnancy.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"xs1r328507","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"21a1y27184","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Diarrhea or recent abdominal surgery:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Avoid intense forward bends if you have diarrhea or have had recent abdominal surgery.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"80vod28510","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yaovl27188","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Insomnia:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" For some individuals, forward bends can be calming, but for others, they may be stimulating. If you find that this pose energizes you rather than relaxes you, practice it earlier in the day.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9e66427210","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"75nvo27191","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always listen to your body and practice mindfully. If you have any concerns about your ability to do this pose safely, consult a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional before attempting it. They can provide personalized guidance and modifications based on your individual needs and limitations.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:46:10.875Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:46:10.875Z","id":"c62a650e-3457-4de5-91d0-4141f8b122d2"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If the Head-to-Knee Pose (Janu Sirsasana) is challenging or not suitable for you due to physical limitations or health concerns, there are several options and alternative poses you can practice to achieve similar benefits. Here are some options:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"l0c1929786","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9009p29787","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"fg82w29706","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Half Head-to-Knee Pose (Ardha Janu Sirsasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Sit with one leg extended and bend the other knee, placing the foot against the inner thigh of the extended leg. Instead of folding over the straight leg, gently hinge forward, keeping the back straight. This modification reduces the intensity of the stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"h0wl029790","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"tfeqq29710","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Seated Forward Bend (Paschimottanasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Sit with both legs extended straight in front of you. Hinge forward at the hips and reach toward your feet. This pose stretches the hamstrings and back, but with less focus on the individual leg's stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"p3puf29793","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"knxdw29714","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Reclining Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose (Supta Padangusthasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Lie on your back and lift one leg off the ground, holding the big toe with your hand. Extend the leg upward while keeping the other leg extended on the floor. This pose stretches the hamstrings without putting pressure on the knee.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"v5jj529796","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"crze729718","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wide-Angle Seated Forward Bend (Upavistha Konasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Sit with your legs spread wide apart in a V shape. Hinge forward at the hips and reach forward with your hands. This pose stretches the inner thighs, hamstrings, and groins.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ke65v29799","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wit5729722","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Standing Forward Bend (Uttanasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Stand with feet hip-width apart, hinge at the hips, and fold forward. This pose provides a gentle stretch to the hamstrings and can be easily modified by bending the knees slightly.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ecd6s29802","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"bitbv29726","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Thread the Needle Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" This seated twist targets the hips, shoulders, and spine, offering a different set of benefits compared to forward bends.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5r19w29805","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wjcht29730","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supine Twist (Supta Matsyendrasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Lie on your back and cross one knee over the other, then gently twist the legs to one side. This pose can help release tension in the spine and improve digestion.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ky8s029857","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"bn7ap29733","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, yoga is about adapting the practice to suit your body's needs and limitations. If any pose feels uncomfortable or painful, listen to your body and modify accordingly. It's always a good idea to seek guidance from a qualified yoga instructor who can help you with appropriate variations and adjustments based on your specific circumstances.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:48:29.135Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:48:29.135Z","id":"8fe15171-57ed-4224-bae9-e4a841cd2c58"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Dancer's Pose with Yoga Strap
Alt Text: How to do Dancer's Pose with a Yoga Strap
Short Description: The Dancer’s Pose, or Natarajasana, with Yoga strap, strengthens the feet, ankles, legs, abdomen, back and arms, Opens the front of the body and the shoulders, and improves balance and focus. Use of a Yoga strap improves access to this pose.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fwl1e246","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Dancer's Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"uusmo1510","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by standing in Mountain pose (Tadasana).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lboxo452","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Press firmly and evenly through your feet. Find a spot to look at on the floor or earth in front of you with a soft gaze.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1ae24490","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. With a soft bend in the left knee, bring your right foot towards the backside.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4lhr9542","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Create a loop with the Yoga strap and use the right hand to loop it over the top of the right foot.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"z9d35608","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Bring the strap over the right shoulder from the back and hold with one or both hands.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vh1s3688","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Make sure the knee and the ankle stay in line with the hip. Draw them in towards the hipline.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fsuiz884","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Straighten the left leg and hug the muscles to the bones in that leg to make it strong.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dx11m984","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Keep the torso upright and the chest/heart open. Lengthen your tailbone down.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"txnp51106","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Move the hand/s down the strap to deepen the pose. Point the elbows to the ceiling with the forearms coming down the back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ww2921242","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. To come out of the pose, gently release the strap and bring the leg down.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ml33t1392","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Repeat on the other side.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T04:02:17.668Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T04:02:17.668Z","id":"099e2116-b84c-4c8f-ad7c-e982631d5333"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mlxpl12645","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform the bend of this pose if you have a back injury.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6qk7q27702","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":", but don't move past it","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":". You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pmknv12671","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This is a strong backbend, make sure you are properly warmed up and prepared before attempting this pose. Try using heart-melting/puppy pose to warm up the shoulders, and a sequence like cow/cat (Bitilasana/Marjaryasana) to warm up the spine, and crescent lunge (Ashta Chandrasana) to warm up the hip flexors, quadriceps and legs.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"65rk012709","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Don’t lock the knee on the standing leg. Use a micro-bend to avoid locking the knee.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n6awc12765","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:11:47.767Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:11:47.767Z","id":"afedfa6d-25b4-495a-8fb8-2b2124ce66de"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the stretch of the back or shoulder is too strenuous, lengthen the strap and use the arm next to the body instead of over the shoulder.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"16w3z16455","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you feel unbalanced, use one hand and use the other hand to steady yourself using a wall, or a chair.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yh3ah16479","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If doing this pose without the Yoga strap, bring the left arm next to the ear and take hold of the right foot (from the inside of the foot or the outside).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:45:46.578Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:45:46.578Z","id":"2e6d5c38-48b4-4499-a68e-075cc465bacf"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Locust Pose
Alt Text: How to do Locust Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Locust Pose, or Salabhasana, strengthens the muscles in the lower back, abdomen, and legs. It helps relieve pain in the lower back and hamstrings.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Locust Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b3pdb","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by lying on your belly, resting your forehead on the floor and arms alongside the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5g7ro","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. From here bend your elbows, bringing the palms of your hands on to the mat and keep the elbows close to the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6fs0b","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Start to activate your legs, extending the toes back away from you and lift up the legs.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"atth5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Now draw your abdomen in and up, as you lift your chest and head off the floor and gaze towards your nose. If you like, you can also straighten your arms alongside the back of your body – reaching your fingertips back away from you. Keep drawing the arms back towards each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"82v2e","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. If the pose feels too intense you can keep your legs on the ground, or keep your hands on the ground close to your body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fc6hd","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay in the pose for five breaths, trying to keep your breathing as smooth as possible. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a8gt3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Then, when you are ready, slowly release the body coming back into the lying pose with your forehead again resting on the floor and arms alongside the body. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:22.446Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:22.446Z","id":"68841ea8-81ba-4696-a374-60abe77751c7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"9l481","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"85uvu","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose when experiencing serious or chronic injuries in the back, arms or shoulders.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"5505c","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose when you’re pregnant or are experiencing menstruation. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"qak6","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:41.105Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:41.105Z","id":"6b52cb79-9874-4195-a461-038251ff3479"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"asqh","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If this pose is too difficult, you can make it easier by only extending and lifting the front part of the body, and keeping your legs on the floor. Additionally, you could straighten your arms alongside the back of your body with the palms of your hands connected to the floor.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:58.653Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:58.653Z","id":"f75b0633-b0fb-4dd2-9d47-890d2112f70d"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Low Plank Pose
Alt Text: How to do Low Plank Pose Yoga Chatauranga
Short Description: The Low Plank Pose, or Four-Limbed Staff Pose, or Chaturanga Dandasana, builds strength and stability in the wrists, arms, shoulders, abdomen, and legs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Low Plank Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7onng","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by coming onto your hands and knees. Make sure your knees are aligned with the hips and your hands with your shoulders or slightly in front.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"95lt0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Spread your fingers widely apart and keep your palms connected to the ground, while you extend your legs out behind you and tuck your toes under.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3ltsb","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Keep reaching your heels back away from you, as you come up into a plank position with the arms straight and chest lifting. Draw your abdomen in, lifting the front of your body back towards the back of the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"931s0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Now lower your body halfway down, by bending your elbows – keeping your muscles in the shoulder, upper arm and core engaged. If you start to collapse, lower the knees down to the floor and then slowly bend your elbows, keeping them close to your body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"93ofc","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Once your upper arms are parallel to the ground, keep your gaze looking forward. Try to hold this position for as long as you can, keep breathing steady. Additionally, keep your focus on having a straight and good form.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ktko","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. To release the pose, slowly lower your body down to the ground as you roll over the toes and connect the tops of the feet to the ground. From here you can keep the arms close to the body and come up towards a cobra pose. From here press back into your hands and find your way back to your hands and knees. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:09.540Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:09.540Z","id":"091119e8-4dd3-401b-997e-c501232f0b04"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"9n419","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"e1sn4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This exercise can be very challenging. If you are unsure whether you are able to do this pose, try the pose first with the knees down on the floor.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"c987a","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This pose is very challenging on the abdominals, the front shoulder muscles, the triceps, and pectoral muscles. Make sure you do not have any injuries in these areas.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"f4ea5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• It can also be stressful on the wrists. If this is the case, try turning the wrists a little more outward and ground the palms of your hands, while spreading your fingers apart. You could also place a steady and sloping object under the hands, which reduces the angle of your wrists and hands, or do this exercise on your fists (though this last suggestion requires extra balance and is thus more difficult).  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"9dluo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Make good use of the muscles to the back of your body to keep good form.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"54mu2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:20.010Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:20.010Z","id":"35137d24-ecdf-4316-b3a8-75c9ac1df64b"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"5v7ag","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Performing this position with the knees on the ground can be a good start when practicing this position.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"6s1hb","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you like to strengthen the abdominal and glute muscles first, you can practice the planking pose first.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"f6uag","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Once you start to lower halfway to the full pose, you can move quickly towards the ground. Over time building up the strength to stay longer balancing halfway down.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:40.917Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:21:40.917Z","id":"f7f734a2-ed2d-4998-bc75-6c2ebdcf5f2c"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Triangle Pose
Alt Text: How to do Triangle Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Triangle Pose or Trikonasana stretches and strengthens the legs, arms, ankles, shoulders, sides of the torso and abdomen. It can also improve digestion.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Triangle Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"74usw117095","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing tall with your arms relaxed at your sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y3i5i117141","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Take a big step back to the right and place your right foot pointing forwards and your left foot pointing out to the left side. Try to align both heels with each other and balance your weight equally across both legs. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"s1bxw117215","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Ground through your feet, as you start to open your right hip and reach both arms out to the sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"eprms117317","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Lengthen and engage the abdominal muscles as you reach your right arm forward. From here reach your right arm down towards your right shin bone or right big toe. Keep lengthening and extending the left side of your torso as you reach your left arm up towards the ceiling. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7ju3z117447","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Extend both your arms away from the heart and allow your left shoulder to open. Try to keep both arms as straight as possible and if it feels comfortable for your neck to start to look up towards your left fingertips. Keeping the chin slightly tucked into the chest. If you start to lose your balance you can keep the gaze looking down. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hr7v3117605","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep pressing into your feet, rolling your right hip back, drawing the belly in and allowing both sides of the torso to extend forward. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"tz3ue117791","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Stay here for at least five long and deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2auy6118005","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. To release, press firmly into your feet and use the strength of your abdomen to come back to standing again. From here, step your right foot back next to the left and then repeat on the left side. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cjw1o118247","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Take a big step back to the left and place your left foot pointing forwards and your right foot pointing out to the right side. Try to align both heels with each other and balance your weight equally across both legs. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6ivz6118517","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Ground through your feet, as you start to open your right hip and reach both arms out to the sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sj2k1118815","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Lengthen and engage the abdominal muscles as you reach your left arm forward. From here, reach your left arm down towards your left shin bone or left big toe. Keep lengthening and extending the left side of your torso as you reach your left arm up towards the ceiling. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jmdez119153","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Extend both your arms away from the heart and allow your right shoulder to open. Try to keep both arms as straight as possible and, if it feels comfortable for your neck, start to look up towards your left fingertips. Keeping the chin slightly tucked into the chest. Again, if you start to lose your balance you can keep the gaze looking down. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"saqmk119507","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. Keep pressing into your feet, rolling your right hip back, drawing the belly in and allowing both sides of the torso to extend forward. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"i9la0119889","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"14. Stay here for at least five long and deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6h5ol120299","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"15. To release, press firmly into your feet and use the strength of your abdomen to come back to standing again. Step from here your left foot back next to the right. Finishing back where you started standing with both feet together. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:58.621Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:58.621Z","id":"26fbb89d-e37d-4249-9e3d-fa1f6497fa36"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"t5fkj121258","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"h26s9121755","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Be careful with your knees: don’t lock them, and do not rest your upper body weight on the knee by leaning onto it in this pose. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"i3wea122280","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Always be careful when experiencing low blood pressure or headaches. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"4y48f122833","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have a neck injury, it is important that you do not turn the neck towards the upper hand. Instead, look ahead or down, whatever feels most comfortable for the neck. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"bzup7123414","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"nzwxb128626","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:32:21.193Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:32:21.193Z","id":"98509efd-4579-4d04-8ec0-3bdb4dc1fbce"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"5v75y125496","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have difficulty finding balance, keep your gaze looking down towards your front foot. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"o0gql128224","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Really press through the feet and activate the legs to make the position easier on the upper body.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:32:38.590Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:32:38.590Z","id":"e3fc17b3-9694-489d-bc5f-0c27e2bf1bd5"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Side Plank Pose
Alt Text: How to do Side Plank Yoga
Short Description: The Side Plank Pose or Vasisthasana builds balance and strength in the legs, arms, shoulders, wrists, and abdomen.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Side Plank Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4jmxi44549","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin on the floor on your hands and knees. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mux6r44595","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Spread the fingers wide apart, grounding through the palms of your hands as you extend your hips up and back to come towards a downward-facing dog pose. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fjkbx44669","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. From here, bring your feet together and your right hand in the middle, as you rotate your whole body to the right side. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"p8g5b44771","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Balance on your right hand and the outside of your right foot, while you lift your hips up and raise your left arm straight up into the air. If stacking your feet on top of each other feels too much you can place your left foot in front of your right. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zvk0t44901","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. You want both arms to keep extending away from your heart and keep your legs really active. Keep reaching your hips up high. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4etul45059","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep a solid posture and, if it feels comfortable for your neck, turn your head to look up towards your left fingertips. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"syl6145245","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. If you can, stay here for five deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lg06945459","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Then, slowly lower your left arm back down and rotate the body back towards the downward-facing dog pose. From here, move towards the pose on the opposite side. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hu3o045701","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Again, bring your feet together and this time your left hand in the middle, as you rotate your whole body to the left side. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"as1az46381","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Balance on your left hand and the outside of your left foot, while you lift your hips up and raise your right arm straight up into the air. Like on your right side, if stacking your feet on top of each other feels too much, you can place your right foot in front of your left. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"po2a946679","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Again, you want both arms to keep extending away from your heart and keep your legs really active. Do not forget to keep reaching your hips up high. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3i1x347005","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Keep a solid posture and, if it feels comfortable for your neck, turn your head to look up towards your right fingertips. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fftua47359","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. If you can, stay here for five deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8nwdx48385","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"14. Then, slowly lower your right arm back down and rotate the body back towards the downward-facing dog pose. From here, drop the knees down to the ground and come back to your hands and knees. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:56:19.389Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:56:19.389Z","id":"222ab1b9-123c-4aa0-98e4-ffcfc1d20025"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"7lnbp49285","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"cwbzf51638","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose if you have an injury in either the arm, wrist or shoulder. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"qflig52135","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:59:46.713Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:59:46.713Z","id":"e9868f63-fb96-49c0-813e-0ee1d56aad55"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"m9zo454211","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This pose requires a lot of strength and stability. You can first begin with getting comfortable holding the plank position for a full minute, before trying to perform this side plank pose. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"rr2o354795","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If stacking the feet on top of each other is too much, you can bring the feet in front of each other.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:10:11.532Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:10:11.532Z","id":"7f8e1209-82dc-49db-b1e5-5adcd83018a5"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Warrior 2
Alt Text: How to do Warrior 2 Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Warrior 2 Pose or Virabhadrasana 2 works on strengthening the legs, and opening the hips and chest.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Warrior 2 Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8sch535044","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing upright with the arms alongside the body. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"j4ifh35046","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Take a big step back, with your right leg and point your right foot forward and left foot out to the left side. Try to align your heels. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e7k0i35048","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. From here, start to deeply bend your right knee, so that your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Open your right knee and right hip to the right side, while keeping your left leg as straight as possible and opening your left hip out to the left side. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"l2l9735050","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Open and extend your arms out to the sides, reaching your fingertips away from your heart. Keep the arms active while you drop the shoulders down and open the front of your chest. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y2zgo35052","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Turn your head towards your right arm and gaze towards your right fingertips. Try to keep your torso in the middle, staying balanced. Stay here for at least five steady and deep breaths. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aham035054","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. When you are ready to come out, release your arms down, straighten your right leg, and step back to the front with both feet together. Change sides and repeat the pose on the left side. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"co37r35056","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Take a big step back with your left leg and point your left foot forward and right foot out to the right side. Try to align your heels. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"op43h35058","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. From here, start to bend deeply your left knee, so that your left thigh is parallel to the ground. Open your left knee and left hip to the left side, while keeping your right leg as straight as possible and opening your right hip out to the right side. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bxvs835060","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Open and extend your arms out to the sides, reaching your fingertips away from your heart. Keep the arms active, while you drop the shoulders down and open the front of your chest. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"kpjyk35062","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Turn your head towards your left arm and gaze towards your left fingertips. Try again to keep your torso in the middle, staying balanced. Stay here for at least five steady and deep breaths. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"f2oy435064","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. When you are ready to come out, release your arms down, straighten your left leg, and step back to the front with both feet together. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:29:06.895Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:29:06.895Z","id":"9be1cc37-bc1c-41bd-990e-f5ff94d82752"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"xre52181751","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"586y1182343","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform the pose if you have an injury in either the hip, knee or shoulder. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"9k00z182756","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:38:38.732Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:38:38.732Z","id":"e8804dae-3121-4752-ae9f-e8abdbccbf72"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"wuwtn185460","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If your hips are too tight. You can shorten the stance by bringing the legs and feet closer together. In this case, your knee will not be 90 degrees bent, but you can make sure the knee is right above your heel. • If you have difficulty holding the arms up, you can place them on your hips.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:38:56.713Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:38:56.713Z","id":"1e0e0105-e492-4e25-89b0-25890952e16b"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Half Lord of the Fishes
Alt Text: How to do Half Lord of the Fishes Pose Yoga
Short Description: Half Lord of the Fishes (Ardha Matsyendrasana) is a seated spinal twist, promoting flexibility, digestion, and energy flow.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Half Lord of the Fishes Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"bin5414510","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6icpk14511","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a6wtd14512","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Start by sitting with your legs extended straight in front of you (staff pose).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ab27r14514","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ulkj914515","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the floor, close to your left thigh.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"nsp3414517","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5xxbt14518","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Slide your left foot under your right leg, bringing it close to your right hip.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9v9bc14520","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gphvn14521","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Ensure both sit bones are firmly rooted on the ground, maintaining an upright posture.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"bzzup14523","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0qv3314524","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Inhale and lengthen your spine, lifting through the crown of your head.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"rek5814526","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"q3lru14527","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As you exhale, twist your torso to the right, placing your left hand on the ground behind you for support.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"tiqfh14529","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"x6b9s14530","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bend your right arm and bring your elbow to the outside of your left knee, pressing your thigh gently with the elbow.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"fyc5014532","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pfg9k14533","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Keep your spine long as you twist, avoiding rounding your back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"08oxs14535","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"kq6kz14536","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Option to place your right hand on the floor behind you or clasp your hands together around your left knee.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"g5j6m14538","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"i6qsf14539","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Relax your shoulders away from your ears and open your chest to deepen the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"r2vc114541","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gincs14542","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hold the pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, breathing deeply and maintaining the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ulrzc14544","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"oyef014545","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To release, gently unwind the twist, coming back to the center.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"sdc7114547","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"siy5h14548","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Straighten your legs and repeat the pose on the other side, bending your left knee this time.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:30:08.471Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:30:08.471Z","id":"27babd27-59d8-48bf-8de1-edc921fe1105"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"While Half Lord of the Fishes (Ardha Matsyendrasana) can be beneficial for many practitioners, there are certain cautions and contraindications to keep in mind:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"cm2bz15562","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5bjzi15563","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xlf5r15564","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Spinal issues:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have a herniated disc, sciatica, or any other serious spinal issues, it's best to avoid or modify this pose. Twisting may exacerbate these conditions.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9ud9i15567","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"08mic15568","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent or chronic injury:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Avoid this pose if you have a recent or chronic injury, especially in the spine, hips, knees, or shoulders.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5p4km15571","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2kmck15572","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Twisting poses can compress the abdomen, which is not suitable during pregnancy. Avoid this pose if you are pregnant.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"kd2fm15575","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zls7o15576","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High or low blood pressure:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Twisting poses can affect blood pressure. If you have high or low blood pressure, be cautious or avoid this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"xor4r15579","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"fdlj115580","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Peptic ulcers or hernias:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Twisting can put pressure on the abdominal area, which may not be suitable for those with peptic ulcers or hernias.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"mzskx15583","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ww6ct15584","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Vertigo or dizziness:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Twisting poses can cause dizziness in some individuals. If you experience vertigo or dizziness, avoid this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"aqrhc15587","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"66klf15588","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent abdominal surgery:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you've had abdominal surgery recently, avoid this pose until you've fully healed.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hzv7l15591","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"w3uhp15592","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wrist or ankle injuries:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Be mindful of your wrist and ankle joints, especially if you have any injuries or limitations in these areas.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"z33sy15595","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"bekmk15596","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" This pose involves twisting, which is generally not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2eqza15599","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always consult with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare provider if you have any concerns or pre-existing medical conditions before attempting Half Lord of the Fishes or any other yoga pose. They can help you with appropriate modifications or suggest alternative poses that suit your needs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:34:20.982Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:34:20.982Z","id":"f8b21e1c-574d-488b-b031-638c287c682d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If you find Half Lord of the Fishes (Ardha Matsyendrasana) challenging or if you have certain physical limitations or conditions that make the full expression of the pose difficult, there are several options and alternatives you can try:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mwghy16584","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Modification with a Block: If you have difficulty reaching the floor with your hand or experience strain in the lower back, place a yoga block under your hand for support. This will help you maintain proper alignment and reduce the intensity of the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4q3pn16586","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Use a Strap: If you have limited shoulder or arm flexibility, you can use a yoga strap to bridge the gap between your hands. Hold the strap with both hands and use it to gently guide the twist, maintaining a comfortable range of motion.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"te67z16588","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Easy Seated Twist: If the seated twist is challenging, you can perform a gentler version by sitting cross-legged and simply twisting your torso to one side, using your hands on your knees for support. This reduces the intensity while still providing benefits.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3yeq716590","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Supine Twist: If you have difficulty sitting on the floor, you can perform a supine twist. Lie on your back, bend your knees, and drop them to one side while keeping your shoulders grounded. This twist can be more accessible and comfortable for some individuals.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"84bkv16592","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Chair Twist: For those with balance issues or limited mobility, you can perform a seated twist in a chair. Sit with your feet flat on the floor, twist your torso to one side, and hold the backrest or the seat of the chair for support.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"akq5o16594","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Supported Twist: Use props like bolsters or cushions to provide support during the twist. This can make the pose more comfortable and help you relax into the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jtq3s16596","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Alternative Twists: If you prefer other twisting poses, you can explore options like Revolved Triangle (Parivrtta Trikonasana) or Revolved Side Angle Pose (Parivrtta Parsvakonasana) to still enjoy the benefits of twists.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"03u8p16796","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"icvqp16598","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, the key is to listen to your body and find a variation that suits your individual needs and capabilities. It's always best to practice under the guidance of a qualified yoga instructor, especially when modifying poses to ensure safety and alignment.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:36:30.894Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:36:30.894Z","id":"a24f35d0-10b0-4c84-a4d7-0ea452a04cb9"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Downward-Facing Dog Pose
Alt Text: How to do Downward-Facing Dog Yoga
Short Description: The Downward-facing Dog Pose, or Adho Mukha Svanasana, stretches and strengthens the wrists, arms, shoulders, abdomen, hips, and legs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Downward-facing Dog Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dh7pn","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by coming on to your hands and knees, spreading your fingers and toes apart and grounding through the palms of your hands. Make sure your knees are aligned with the hips and your arms with your shoulders.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3gbbu","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Now tuck your toes under and extend your hips up and back, as you reach the crown of your head towards the ground. Keep grounding through your index finger and thumb.  3. You can keep your knees slightly bent, to begin with, as you lengthen your spine by pushing your hips to the ceiling. Straighten your legs if it feels comfortable and allow your heels to drop down towards the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7v0r3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep pressing the palms of your hands into the ground and from there lift up towards your shoulders and hips. Keep opening and lengthening the space in the front of your shoulders. Gaze back towards your navel, keeping the chin tucked into the chest.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9cdh5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Stay in the pose for at least five long and deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3hv3f","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Once you are ready to come out, gently lower your knees down to the ground and come back to your hands and knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:51:36.615Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:51:36.615Z","id":"44377426-fe1f-4297-9dc2-953889694923"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"46emg","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"6spt7","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Because this exercise can be hard on the wrists, it is important to not perform this pose or modify it, when you have painful or weak wrists. You can modify the position and make it easier on your wrists by coming onto your forearms or performing it with a cushion underneath the palms of your hands.
