","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"d1gjc","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this position when you are in late-term pregnancy  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"66qor","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything of this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:52:00.609Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:52:00.609Z","id":"e1fecf00-42d3-4609-8b91-d4ef516e19b7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"70j0g30970","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Keeping the knees comfortably bent is a great way to make this pose easier. Also, do not worry too much if the heels do not touch the floor.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"1i1f","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could also start by practicing against a wall. Place both hands against the wall and keep a slight bend in the knees. Now push your torso through the arms, with a straight spine, and contract the shoulder blades. This exercise resembles the standing forward bend pose but is an easier variation.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:52:58.172Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:52:58.172Z","id":"e5f57615-7cbe-4313-812b-e4d4091f5932"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Wheel Pose
Alt Text: How to do Wheel Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Wheel Pose or Urdhva Dhanurasana opens the shoulders and chest and lengthens the spine.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Wheel Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"l7p2q216619","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by lying flat on your back. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e50zq216665","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend your knees and place your feet parallel and hip-distance apart. Your heels can be close to your hips. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"addkh216742","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Place your hands close to your shoulders, with your fingertips pointing towards your hips. Keep drawing your elbows towards each other while spreading your fingertips and grounding the palms of your hands into the floor. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"in2md216844","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Now draw your abdomen in and push your hips up. Press your feet into the ground as you activate your legs, reaching your inner thighs slightly forward and towards each other. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"637lw216974","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Stay here for a few steady and deep breaths. If its enough for you, you can stay here. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"00yn4217132","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Then, on an inhale press into the palms of your hands, keep the elbows drawing in towards each other and push from the arms upwards. Really press through the hands to, either bring the crown of your head onto the floor or to go for the full expression of the pose by straightening the arms fully. Extend and lift your chest upwards, opening the front of your shoulders. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5gfvn217318","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Focus on drawing your belly in, lifting the chest and pushing the hips a little higher up; perhaps even lengthening the arms further if you have space. Allow your head to hang. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"l57uc217532","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. If you can, stay here for five long deep breaths keeping your gaze looking down. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"99a2r217757","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. To release, tuck your chin into your chest and slowly bring the back of your head and hips down to the ground. Extend the legs back out in front of you and rest. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:40:06.847Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:40:06.847Z","id":"68b57a55-4764-4089-8ae3-b8913d01e622"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"2cew2218187","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"9ufay218362","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not practice this pose if you are currently experiencing headaches, dizziness, or if you have problems with your heart. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"xqcdc218691","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This exercise requires a lot of strength and balance, so if you are inexperienced or don’t have the strength yet, it would be better to first try an easier version of this pose. You can find the easier versions under ‘Options’. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"ap1kn219048","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:40:17.088Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:40:17.088Z","id":"11f48d88-ad9a-4cb7-a605-d4ee395d0f95"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"co4ep222653","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you would like to make the pose easier, you can rest the head on the floor instead of lifting it off. Rest the head with the crown on the floor. Make sure the pressure on the neck and head is low, by engaging the arms. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"yy56l222210","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you still find the alternate version with the head on the floor too difficult, you can do this pose lifting only the hips off the floor. Build up arm strength with poses like the Plank Pose or the Low Plank pose and open the front of your shoulders with a pose like the Cow Face Pose.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"tppcs222928","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:23.082Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:23.082Z","id":"224f753b-fc0b-407d-ae56-f430e47efa62"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Plank Pose
Alt Text: How to do Plank Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Plank Pose, or Phalakasana, strengthens the wrists, arms, shoulders, abdominal muscles and legs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Plank Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"32q9r","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by coming onto your hands and knees. Make sure your knees are aligned with the hips and your hands with your shoulders or slightly in front of them.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"65meh","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Spread your fingers widely apart and keep your palms connected to the ground, while you extend your legs out behind you and tuck your toes under.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5q1ta","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Keep reaching your heels back away from you as you come up into a plank pose with the arms straight and chest lifting. Draw your abdomen in, lifting the front of your body back towards the back of the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"64qbb","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep your head and gaze looking forward, as you stay here for at least five long and deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7b6t","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. When you are ready to come out of the pose, you can slowly drop your knees down to the floor, coming back to your hands and knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:48:58.409Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:48:58.409Z","id":"981cb5c4-1052-423a-af49-1fec0b422b5f"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"dbi8e","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"573vl","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"•This is can be a strenuous exercise for your abdominal muscles, so watch out if you have any known problems or weaknesses in that area.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"4ni1o","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"•This can also be hard on your wrists. To resolve this you can practice the plank on your elbows, turn your hands a little outward, or use a steady and sloping object for your hands, so the angle of your wrists and hands is reduced.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"clvh5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"•If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:49:21.291Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:49:21.291Z","id":"67187652-58db-4b1a-90b5-1ac120d8fe5d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"cmgr0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• To make this pose easier on the wrist, please read above ‘cautions’.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"96paf","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• To make this pose easier for your abdominal muscles, or easier overall, perform this pose on your knees and hands/elbows instead of on your feet and hands.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:49:52.239Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:49:52.239Z","id":"0cffa9c0-2256-4c70-8de5-4aaa7ae43741"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Boat Pose
Alt Text: How to do boat pose yoga navasana
Short Description: Navasana, or Boat Pose, is a challenging yoga posture that strengthens the core and improves balance, resembling a boat shape.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Boat Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zd99w2080","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Sit on the yoga mat with your legs extended in front of you, spine straight, and arms beside your hips.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4kifb1192","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend your knees and lift your feet off the floor, balancing on your sitting bones, forming a \"V\" shape with your body.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1wsk81194","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Bring your shins parallel to the floor, keeping your calves in line with your thighs, and engage your core muscles.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ghuk71196","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Lengthen your tailbone towards the floor, maintaining a straight back and an open chest.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"65hz91198","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Extend your arms forward, parallel to the ground, palms facing each other.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vl20e1200","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep your gaze focused on a fixed point to aid your balance.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"135ps1202","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Ensure your knees and toes are in alignment, avoiding them from splaying outward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pmbjw1204","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Breathe steadily and deeply as you hold the pose for a comfortable duration (start with 10-20 seconds).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a4mk71206","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. For a more challenging variation, straighten your legs, keeping them at a 45-degree angle to the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"355r71208","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. To intensify further, slowly lower your upper body towards the floor while maintaining the balance.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mnzj51210","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. To release, exhale and gently lower your feet back to the floor, returning to the starting seated position.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"00fw81212","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Take a moment to relax, and repeat the pose for 2-3 more sets, gradually increasing the duration as you build strength.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T00:52:33.922Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T00:52:33.922Z","id":"8de70a88-a9a7-4f85-adac-bd5eae71c1ba"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"ek7i9","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything of this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"l6eju3457","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always consult with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional before attempting Boat Pose, especially if you have any medical conditions or concerns. They can guide you on proper alignment and modifications to ensure your practice is safe and suitable for your individual needs.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"kwd7c2879","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy: Avoid practicing Boat Pose during pregnancy, especially in the later stages, as it puts pressure on the abdomen and could be uncomfortable or risky.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"m46h72881","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Low back or neck issues: Individuals with lower back pain or injuries should be cautious with this pose, as it can strain the lumbar region. Those with neck issues should also avoid excessive straining of the neck and focus on keeping the neck relaxed.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ik0bx2883","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High blood pressure: Boat Pose can be physically demanding and may cause a spike in blood pressure. People with uncontrolled high blood pressure should avoid this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4hpb22885","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Asthma or respiratory conditions: The intense engagement of the core and breath control in this pose can be challenging for individuals with respiratory issues. It is best to avoid or modify the pose accordingly.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qbpur2887","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Diarrhea or digestive issues: Boat Pose can put pressure on the abdomen, which may exacerbate digestive problems or discomfort.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"x9mni2889","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent abdominal surgery: If you've had recent abdominal surgery, avoid Boat Pose until you have fully recovered and received clearance from your doctor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"t8naq2891","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"•  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hip injuries: People with or hip injuries should be cautious while performing this pose, as it requires support from the hips.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gf21e2893","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T00:53:23.783Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T00:53:23.783Z","id":"cb11e560-f574-4841-8e07-d00c276a0fbd"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"b77xe4369","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"aff084370","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9qofp4287","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Half Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Keep one foot on the floor while lifting the other leg and extending the corresponding arm forward. Switch sides after holding for a few breaths.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"gqot44373","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qwta74291","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supported Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Use yoga blocks or a bolster under your feet for added support and reduced intensity.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6rhm44376","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vfwa94295","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"One-Legged Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Lift one leg off the floor while keeping the other extended. Switch legs after holding for a desired duration.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"vvcsw4379","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jwk864299","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Dynamic Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" From a seated position, lift and lower your legs in a controlled motion, engaging the core.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6geu64382","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"q38054303","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Low Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Instead of lifting the legs high, keep them close to the floor, supporting your balance with your hands if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"n78bs4385","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"haixh4307","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall-assisted Boat Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Perform the pose with your back against a wall for stability and support.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6oo8h4388","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2h6ck4311","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Breathing Variation:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Inhale as you lift your legs and exhale as you lower them, synchronizing breath with movement.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"9vpar4314","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember to modify the pose according to your fitness level and any existing health conditions. Always listen to your body, and if you experience any pain or discomfort, discontinue the pose and consult a yoga instructor or healthcare professional for guidance.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:00:10.149Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:00:10.149Z","id":"eb9ef9db-4f65-46bc-a08a-e201db28f769"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Crescent High Lunge
Alt Text: How to do High Lunge Crescent Pose Yoga
Short Description: Crescent High Lunge is an energizing yoga pose that stretches the hip flexors, builds leg strength, and opens the chest for balance and focus.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Crescent High Lunge can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n76b07715","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in a standing position at the top of your mat, with your feet hip-width apart and arms relaxed by your sides.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yp3gu7717","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Step your right foot back about 3 to 4 feet, ensuring your feet are aligned in a straight line, and your toes pointing forward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"is9no7719","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Bend your left knee to create a 90-degree angle, making sure your knee is directly above your ankle, not extending past it.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ekxe87721","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep your right leg straight and strong, with the heel lifted off the mat and the toes pressing firmly into the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bzvfz7723","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. As you inhale, engage your core and lift your torso, reaching your arms overhead, palms facing each other.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"x80mu7725","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Draw your tailbone down and lengthen your spine, avoiding overarching your back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9f28g7727","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep your shoulders relaxed, away from your ears, and your chest open.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"u1gta7729","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Gaze forward or slightly upward to maintain balance and focus.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"tooeg7731","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. To deepen the stretch, slightly tilt your pelvis forward and gently press your hips down towards the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"trzgw7733","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Hold the pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, breathing deeply and steadily.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"t34zm7735","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. To release the pose, exhale and lower your arms back down by your sides.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qh3aq7737","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Step your right foot forward to meet your left foot, returning to the starting position.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mg3mr7739","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. Repeat the same steps on the other side by stepping your left foot back and bending your right knee.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"nkc2t7741","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:08:43.240Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:08:43.240Z","id":"0514f9da-d031-4efb-a617-9d0ac60aa7a8"},"documentStyle":{}}

safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"j1e8b9353","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"75tk49354","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"oeym69355","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Knee Blood Pressure:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Caution for those with uncontrolled high blood pressure.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"mu90c9362","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"figd39363","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Heart surgeries.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"3l32u9366","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8yo9c9367","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Balance Issues:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Be careful if you experience difficulties with balance or dizziness.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"1qjik9370","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jsb1t9371","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Neck injuries.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"4frro9374","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0pma69375","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Modify or avoid the pose, especially during later stages of pregnancy.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"i728a9378","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gtbil9393","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Here are some alternative variations and options for the Crescent High Lunge pose:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"xxnz211403","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"t9nmx11404","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ib81011360","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Low Lunge: Keep the back knee on the mat for a gentler version, providing more support to the knees and hips.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jmo0211406","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gb8w711362","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supported Crescent Lunge: Use yoga blocks under the hands to decrease the stretch and provide stability.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"sr6r511408","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3gy3911364","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Warrior I: Transition to Warrior I by aligning both feet forward, squaring the hips, and bending the front knee at a 90-degree angle.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hhlit11410","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"csyhb11366","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Twisting Crescent Lunge: Add a gentle twist by placing the opposite elbow on the outside of the front knee and extending the other arm upward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jihf311412","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pcyg611368","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Crescent Lunge with Back Knee Down: Instead of straightening the back leg, keep the back knee on the floor to ease pressure on the hip flexors.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"8eato11414","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5z2h311370","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall-assisted Crescent Lunge: Stand facing a wall and place your hands on it for extra balance and support.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"er0u111416","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ie9lu11372","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Crescent Lunge with Back Heel Supported: Press the back heel against a wall or a stable surface for added stability.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"59jpv11418","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lfflx11374","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Crescent Lunge with Hands on Hips: Instead of reaching arms overhead, keep your hands on your hips to modify the upper body engagement.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ttxyn11420","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"uwze411376","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Crescent Lunge with a Chair: Use a chair for support and balance, especially if you have trouble maintaining stability on your own.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aq8jq11378","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember to choose the variation that best suits your body and level of comfort. Each modification allows you to adjust the intensity of the pose, making it accessible to a wider range of practitioners, from beginners to those with specific physical limitations. As always, practice mindfully, and if you have any medical concerns, consult with a healthcare professional.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:15:46.105Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:15:46.105Z","id":"7596143d-a7c5-42d5-9129-e20e5b68c9a6"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Easy Pose
Alt Text: How to do Easy Pose Yoga
Short Description: Easy Pose, or Sukhasana, is sitting cross-legged. It is known as the seat of meditation, and is the only pose mentioned in Patanjali ancient text, the Yoga Sutras.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Easy Pose","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mphe75604","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"sitting down","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"k7y1j5608","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cross one shin in front of the other","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"p3fl75612","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Sit evenly on the sitting bones.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ikcdh5615","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lengthen the spine, with the crown of the head reaching up towards the sky.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"av9hz5618","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Tuck the chin slightly so it’s on the same level or plane as the forehead.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:08:14.205Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:08:14.205Z","id":"09f040b1-8d67-4977-b60c-cdd86e074e35"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"iqdt36614","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not do this pose if you have ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"hip or knee issues","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"tdzy86618","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"j81p96620","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:08:56.277Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:08:56.277Z","id":"78394a5b-b120-4917-970b-0267ff6a64e7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"rqeiy7238","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the spine is rounded, or it is uncomfortable sitting in this pose, try sitting on the edge of a block, or on a cushion or a folded blanket to lift the hips. The knees can also be supported by sliding blocks, cushions or folded blankets underneath the upper thighs.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:09:20.755Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:09:20.755Z","id":"c854a73e-b2ce-4673-bc0d-d7f5a4b1db98"}}

Title: Sun Salutation
Alt Text: How to do Sun Salutation A
Short Description: The Sun Salutation or Surya Namaskar steps are performed in a flowing motion as a way to warm up the body and increase blood circulation. Every sun salutation step is linked to an inhale or exhale, the inhales focusing on lengthening and extending, and the exhales on bending and strengthening. The key to the sun salutation steps is the fluent motion in which you perform this sequence of poses. You should not stay still, so even if the explanation seems long, it is important you perform every part – and in between every part - in a flowing motion.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Sun Salutation Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"wdgle11627","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing tall with your arms relaxed to the sides. Your feet can be together or hip-distance apart. Take a couple of breaths here, before starting flowing to find an equal inhale and exhale. You want to try to maintain the same length of the breath throughout the sequence.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n4jfu11629","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. On the next inhale, circle the arms upwards towards the ceiling, gazing up towards your thumbs.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5i0gs11631","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Then exhale, as you draw the abdomen in and fold forward, as you circle the arms all the way down to the ground. If you need you can bend the knees so that your hands can rest on the floor. Keep the head heavy.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9ds4b11633","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Inhale again and lengthen the spine halfway up, so your torso is parallel to the floor and gazes forward. If needed your fingers can lift up from the ground here so that your spine can completely straighten.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qm7zt11635","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Now place the palms of your hands on the floor, bending the knees if you need as you exhale and step or lightly jumping back into the plank pose. On the same exhale bend the elbows and lower the body halfway down, keep gazing forward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ybcky11637","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Then inhale, as you roll over your toes and bring your chest forward and up, straightening your arms. Press your feet into the floor, as you keep the abdomen in and chest opening.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4mg9511639","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Exhale, rolling over your toes and lifting your hips up and back towards the downward-facing dog pose. Keep your abdomen drawing in and allow the front of your shoulders to open, gaze back towards your belly.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vsmbx11641","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Inhale and slowly walk, step or jump your feet towards your hands, as you lift the chest halfway up, gazing forward. The abdomen is drawing in and again if needed, allow your fingertips to lift from the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bryl111643","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Then exhale again and fold forward from the hips, dropping the weight of your head down. Keeping a slight bend in the knees.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cvndu11645","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Then, on an inhale, circle the arms up as you come all the way back up to standing and gaze up towards your thumbs, palms together.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"64zw211647","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Exhale, circle the arms back down alongside your body.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9e5hk11649","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. You can repeat this another three or five rounds until you feel warmed up and ready to approach some of the other poses.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:18:11.072Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:18:11.072Z","id":"6eb3dde3-18a6-4f9c-b5f8-70c312394e0d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jrl8013607","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose/a sequence of poses. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the poses working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"j81p96620","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:19:56.915Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-01-23T04:19:56.915Z","id":"3cc22cb3-7f3f-4a56-ac23-d1355daf674f"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Bound Angle Pose Butterfly
Alt Text: How to do Bound Angle Pose Butterfly Yoga
Short Description: The Butterfly Pose, or Baddha Konasana, stretches and strengthens the hip muscles and inner thighs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Butterfly Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dcc2s","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in a seated position with your legs stretched out in front of you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bv8h","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend your knees, bring the soles of your feet together, and bring your heels to close towards your hips. The outside of your feet should be connected to the ground. Open your inner thighs to the sides and allow your knees to naturally drop down towards the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"th3n","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Hold the inner arches of your feet with your hands and gently rotate the insides of your feet outwards.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6mces","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep your weight grounding down through your sitting bones – not leaning the upper body too far forward or back. You want to be sitting upright, allowing your abdomen to engage and lift upwards and your lower back muscles to support you from behind.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2vd98","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Keep drawing the shoulders down and back, and lift your chest slightly up towards your chin which is tucking back down to your chest. Make sure your neck and head are aligned with the spine and not leaning towards the left or right side. Keep the gaze of your eyes looking down towards the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"55k9q","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay in this pose for at least five long and steady breaths, trying to make each breath deeper and deeper.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9sqih","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. If it feels comfortable you can try to fold forward from the hips after a few breathes to get a deeper stretch.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fit3i","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. You want to find a depth where you can feel a stretch that is not too forceful or light. While you work on deepening the stretch become aware in which parts of the body you feel tightness and direct your focus to this point using the breath to soften and release tension. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c9vir","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. After several breaths or even several minutes, gently release the pose by coming slowly back up with the upper body to an upright and neutral position. Now place your hands under the outside of your knees and bring the knees towards each other. Stretch out the legs in front of you.   ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:30.911Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:30.911Z","id":"c8768852-d628-44b7-8ea9-76f6b539b185"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ek7i9","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything of this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:02.148Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:02.148Z","id":"83262be4-2b3b-4a1b-8fcf-b0ee8d4ac6aa"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3crcl35799","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• It is not necessary for the outside of your knees to connect to the floor, but you want to avoid having your knees too high from the floor. If your knees are particularly high you can lower them by sitting upon support like a cushion to give the hips a bit more space. This will make it easier for you to drop the knees down and get the most out of the stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:51.729Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:01:51.729Z","id":"fb8eb638-6b28-4c30-bcbd-87361c0ac63f"}}

Title: Standing Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose Side Variation with Yoga Strap
Alt Text: How to do Standing Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose Side Variation Yoga
Short Description: Standing Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose Side Variation with Yoga strap, or Utthita Hasta Padangusthasana, is a standing and balancing pose on one leg. It targets the lower body, particularly the hamstrings, and releases the lower back.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Standing Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Pose Side Variation with Yoga strap can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ooo6s55882","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by standing.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"q1r0l55884","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Hold the Yoga strap in the right hand. Bend the right knee and loop the strap over the ball of the right foot.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xq5va55886","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Straighten the right leg moving the hand along the strap making sure your torso is upright.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3p0xi55888","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Have the left hand on the hip.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"x5n7d55890","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Flex the foot, making sure the second toe lines up with the middle of the ankle crease so the toes are facing up towards the sky.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jp0l655892","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lift the leg higher ensuring your back is straight","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"42zea55896","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. The left leg is straight. Press the foot down into the floor. Hug the muscles to the bones in ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"the","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" legs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"f06z355900","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Keeping the hips even, open the right leg out to the side, moving the hand along the strap accordingly.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vb6cq55903","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. To come out of the pose bring the leg back to centre, bend the knee, remove the strap and release the foot down to the ground.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"kzy3g55905","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Repeat on the other side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:38:57.298Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:38:57.298Z","id":"c2ab2a20-0ade-4adf-bc18-3535373e8edd"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8r0so57091","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Be careful not to lock the knees","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":". Have tiny bend/s in the knee/s if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2ewo557095","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Be careful of your back. Do not round through the back. Make sure the spine stays long and the shoulders soften away from the ears.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"n1ahx57097","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5jh3q57099","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:39:29.247Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:39:29.247Z","id":"28c0ade3-ff61-4efa-b325-905c2da1da85"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• The lifted leg can have a bend in the knee if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gwpwa57758","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Move the leg higher or lower by moving the hands up or down the strap to increase or decrease intensity.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ftg5d57760","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:41:47.809Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:41:47.810Z","id":"0a0d55d1-f59f-41b3-9efd-5a89c3919080"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Warrior 3
Alt Text: How to do Warrior 3 Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Warrior 3 Pose or Virabhadrasana 3 improves your overall balance and works on strengthening the legs, ankles, and abdomen.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Warrior 3 Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"rzpj537368","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start standing upright with your arms alongside the body. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"rqoqb37370","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Have your feet close together with either your big toes touching or feet hip-width apart. Your knees can be slightly bent, toes spreading apart and legs active. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dd6mm37372","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Now shift your weight to your left leg, making it firm and long, while you start to slowly lift your right leg back behind you. Both legs should stay as straight as possible. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jaskb37374","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Start to lengthen the front of your body, engaging the abdomen as you reach and fold forward with your torso. From here, extend your arms all the way over your head, reaching your fingertips out in front of you. Straighten the arms, so your legs, torso, and arms are aligned. Your right foot is reaching back, while the crown of the head and fingertips are reaching in the opposite direction forward. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gox2k37376","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. If reaching the arms forward feels like too much you can bring your hands in front of the heart or keep them alongside the body. If it’s difficult to balance place your fingertips on the ground. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jivyg37378","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Finding a straight standing leg will help with your balance and then you can work on also straightening the lifted leg as much as you can. Keep an active and straight posture and focus on your breathing. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bml1s37380","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Hold the pose for at least five, long breaths, with your gaze looking forward. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"q2zxm37382","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. When you are ready slowly release the pose by lowering your right leg back next to your left leg. Standing back with both legs next to each other. From here change and repeat balancing on the opposite leg. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zp7m637384","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Now shift your weight to your right leg, making it firm and long, while you start to slowly lift your left leg back behind you. Again, both legs should stay as straight as possible. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b066h37386","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Start to lengthen the front of your body, engaging the abdomen as you reach and fold forward with your torso. From here, extend your arms all the way over your head, reaching your fingertips out in front of you. Straighten the arms, so your legs, torso, and arms are aligned. Now your left foot is reaching back, while the crown of the head and fingertips are reaching in the opposite direction forward. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ob4xz37388","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Again, if it feels too much reaching the arms forward bring your hands once more in front of the heart, alongside the body or on the ground. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0g22q37390","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Finding a straight standing leg will help with your balance and then you can work on also straightening the lifted leg as much as you can. Keep an active and straight posture and focus on your breathing. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6twzc37392","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. Hold the pose for at least five, long breaths, with your gaze looking forward. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"s0am537394","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"14. When you are ready, slowly release the pose by lowering your left leg back next to your right leg. Standing back with both legs next to each other. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:30:09.059Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:30:09.059Z","id":"1e9d6ccc-1300-4241-8b1f-8b87e1892ec0"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"w4ppi199744","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"g6mtl199999","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This can be a strenuous exercise, requiring a lot of balance. It is important you are feeling rested and ready for exercise when practicing this position. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"x3w62200468","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose when you are experiencing nausea, headaches or dizziness. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"zrnlf200965","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:39:33.596Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:39:33.596Z","id":"45a4530b-9053-4ab2-afdc-76a0e0936fc9"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"s65ih201787","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• A slightly easier version can be performed by keeping the arms alongside the body or by bringing the hands together in front of the heart. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"mhdy0204019","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the balance is challenging you could keep your fingertips balancing on the floor or against the wall or chair. Make sure the distance to the wall or chair is big enough so you can extend the arms and legs, and only touch the wall or chair when the body is close to or is parallel to the floor.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:39:49.324Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:39:49.324Z","id":"8ade04bb-43a9-4b73-8d37-608c34c4dbdf"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Low Lunge
Alt Text: How to do a Yoga lunge
Short Description: Low lunge: A yoga pose that stretches the hip flexors and opens the chest, promoting flexibility, balance, and strengthening legs. Benefits include improved posture and reduced tension.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Low Lunge can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pj21i32518","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in a standing position at the top of your mat with feet hip-width apart, arms at your sides, and palms facing forward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dlfid32520","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Take a deep breath in and as you exhale, step your right foot back, creating a long stance with your left foot forward and right foot extended straight behind you.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"isajb32522","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Lower your right knee to the mat gently, placing it directly under your right hip, and uncurl your toes, allowing the top of your right foot to rest on the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fcpjy32524","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Check your alignment by ensuring that your left knee is stacked directly over your left ankle, forming a 90-degree angle, and keep your left shin vertical to the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ck3jn32526","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. As you inhale, lift your chest and torso, engaging your core and lengthening your spine.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0v3nc32528","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. If comfortable, raise your arms overhead, reaching toward the sky, with palms facing each other or coming into prayer position.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"z51wh32530","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. To deepen the stretch, gently sink your hips forward and down, feeling the opening in the front of your right hip and thigh.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"z3w1l32532","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Hold the pose for 30 seconds to one minute, breathing deeply and steadily, maintaining your balance.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mo6t232534","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. To release, exhale and lower your hands back down to the mat on either side of your left foot.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2m8ym32536","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Step your left foot back to meet your right in a plank position or come to your hands and knees.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"r6u0z32538","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Optionally, move through a vinyasa by lowering yourself to Chaturanga, arching into Upward-Facing Dog, and then pushing back to Downward-Facing Dog.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"95uem32540","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Repeat the Low Lunge on the other side by stepping your left foot back and following the same steps.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0e6et32585","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0eigw32542","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember to listen to your body and modify the pose as needed. Low Lunge is an excellent pose for building strength, flexibility, and balance while providing a deep stretch to the hip flexors and thighs.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:55:11.023Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T02:55:11.023Z","id":"3f38396e-0546-4a16-83d2-c8c5d198aba6"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"c610433802","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jeko533771","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"78uue33772","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Knee or ankle injuries:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have knee or ankle problems, be cautious when performing Low Lunge. You may want to use extra padding under your knee or avoid the pose altogether.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"qrtn233775","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7w4bn33776","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hip issues:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Individuals with hip injuries, such as labral tears or hip replacements, should avoid or modify this pose to prevent further discomfort or injury.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"wd0mg33779","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"4y9np33780","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High blood pressure:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" For those with high blood pressure, raising the arms overhead in Low Lunge can potentially increase blood pressure, so it's better to keep the hands on the hips or in a prayer position.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"bogd733783","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"cjkd633784","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Back problems:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have a history of lower back issues, be mindful of how far you sink into the lunge, and avoid over-arching the lower back.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"y2ij533787","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ek9s833788","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Pregnant women should take caution with this pose, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.
