Seated Spinal Twist: Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you. Cross one foot over the other leg and place it on the floor, then twist your torso toward the bent knee. You can use your opposite hand to support you in the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vfqsz49840","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Supine Twist with Bent Legs: Lie on your back, bend your knees, and let them fall to one side while keeping your feet on the ground. This is a gentle twist that provides a nice stretch to the lower back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"00pze49842","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Cat-Cow Stretch: Come into a tabletop position and alternate between arching your back (Cow Pose) and rounding your back (Cat Pose). This gentle spinal movement can help relieve tension and improve flexibility.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"w1wo349844","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Revolved Abdomen Pose (Bharadvajasana): Sit with your legs extended in front of you, then bend one knee and place the foot outside the opposite thigh. Twist your torso toward the bent knee, using your arm for support. This seated twist offers a different variation of the twist.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"r075149846","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember to perform any modifications mindfully and listen to your body. If you have specific concerns or health issues, consult with a yoga instructor or healthcare professional to find the most suitable alternatives for your needs. Yoga is a versatile practice, and there are plenty of options to adapt poses to your individual capabilities and goals.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:48:01.671Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:48:01.671Z","id":"97993e8c-d633-4ee9-a9a0-70f31f9799d0"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Reclining Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose
Alt Text: How do do Reclining Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose
Short Description: Reclining Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe pose with Yoga strap, or Supta Utthita Hasta Padangusthasana, targets the lower body, particularly the hamstrings, and releases the lower back.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Reclining Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe pose with Yoga strap can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"18ziv20818","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by lying down. There should be a slight, natural arch in the lower back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8mkfh20820","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend the right knee and lift the leg enough to bring the strap around the sole of the foot.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2hc9p20822","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Flex the foot, making sure the second toe lines up with the middle of the ankle crease.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lenif20824","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Hold one strap end in each hand and extend the leg.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8m6rw20826","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. The left leg is straight along the floor. The foot is flexed with the toes facing up towards the sky. Press the leg down into the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"efpax20828","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Hug the muscles to the bones in the legs.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3kw3i20830","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Move the hands upwards along the strap to deepen the stretch, drawing the leg closer towards the face.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6qcmm20832","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Repeat on the other side.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:07:38.478Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:07:38.478Z","id":"ee2bd782-6a01-4581-b8e4-7a493eb6321e"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"wtbnl22474","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Be careful not to lock the knee with the leg that is lifted. Have a tiny bend in the knee if needed. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jgt6e22476","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don't move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6pgza22478","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:08:52.242Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:08:52.242Z","id":"cc3ed89b-92d2-4edb-9059-292f5a47c0c3"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In yoga, the Reclining Extended Hand to Big Toe Pose is a variation of the classic Extended Hand to Big Toe Pose (Utthita Hasta Padangusthasana). The reclining version is often more accessible for people with limited flexibility or those who are beginners in their yoga practice. However, if you find this pose challenging or have certain physical limitations, there are alternative options to achieve similar benefits. Here are some options and alternatives:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"9t2km51244","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"muvyd51245","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jyj8s51246","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Reclining Extended Hand to Big Toe Pose (Supta Padangusthasana):","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" This is the reclining version of the pose, where you lie on your back and extend one leg upward while holding the big toe with your hand. The other leg remains extended on the ground.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"blhfm51249","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"6kgtr51250","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Using a Strap:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you cannot reach your big toe comfortably in the reclining version, you can use a yoga strap or a belt. Loop the strap around the sole of your foot and hold onto the ends of the strap with your hands. This allows you to extend your leg without straining or overstretching.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"rnpcp51253","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"qbgfv51254","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall Support:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Perform the Reclining Extended Hand to Big Toe Pose near a wall. Extend your leg upward and place the sole of your foot against the wall. The wall will provide support, making it easier to keep your leg extended.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9kyme51257","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8pns751258","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bent Knee Variation:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have tight hamstrings, bending the extended leg slightly can make the pose more accessible. Keep the knee slightly bent while holding the big toe or strap.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"oaldv51261","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"4iqc851262","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"One-Legged Reclining Pigeon Pose:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Lie on your back and bend one knee towards your chest. Cross the ankle of the bent leg over the opposite knee and hold the back of the thigh or shin of the bent leg. This pose provides a stretch for the hip and the hamstrings.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"upw1h51265","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"dw9f251266","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supine Hamstring Stretch:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Lie on your back and use a strap or a yoga band to loop around your foot. Keeping both legs straight, gently pull the strap to bring your leg closer to your chest, stretching the hamstring.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pgk0q51269","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, it's essential to listen to your body and not force yourself into any position that causes pain or discomfort. Always warm up properly before attempting any deep stretches, and if you're new to yoga or have any health concerns or injuries, consider consulting a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional for guidance tailored to your specific needs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:49:36.220Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:49:36.220Z","id":"fda7baa8-a486-4153-ba00-c23d116ef5e9"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Wide-Legged Forward Bend
Alt Text: How to do Wide-Legged Forward Bend Yoga
Short Description: The Wide-legged Forward Bend Pose or Prasarita Padottanasana stretches and opens the legs, hips, and spine. It can also have a calming effect on the nervous system.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Wide-legged Forward Bend Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sk6gk234275","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing tall with your arms relaxed to your sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"x4xdg234321","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Now, take a big step back with your right foot and bring your feet parallel, with your big toes facing inwards and heels outwards. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yc2ow234395","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Now straighten and lengthen the upper body, as you bring your hands to your hips and draw the elbows back towards each other. Keep your spine nice and long, as you slowly start to fold forward from the hips and reach the crown of the head down. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n958r234497","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. From here, place your hands on the floor under your shoulders, bending the knees a little if you need it. Keep maintaining a long spine, as you draw your abdomen in, open your shoulders and keep the legs active. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5itye234627","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. If you feel any resistance or trembling, hold the position firmly and try to breathe deeply and steadily. Gaze softly forward. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"to6ez234785","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. After a couple of breaths, lengthen your body and bring your hips a bit further towards the ceiling on a long inhale. Use then a long exhale to perhaps folding forward, walking your hands closer in line with your feet and dropping the head down towards the ground. If you like, you can try moving in and out a couple of times, if it helps to deepen the stretch. Keep listening to your body and your breath. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o248v234971","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Stay here for at least five breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aw7qp235185","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. When you are ready to come out of the pose, slowly pushing your torso halfway up on an inhale. Bringing then your hands to your hips, and using the strength of your abdomen, to come all the way back up to standing again. From here, step your right foot back next to the left foot, coming back to where you started with both feet together. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:43.185Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:43.185Z","id":"b285c23f-d4f2-40df-9f6a-06b80943b70f"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"c8315235731","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"qe2lt236032","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform the bend of this pose if you have a back injury. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"leslu236361","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:53.067Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:41:53.067Z","id":"4af56445-0df8-4741-89eb-a8ab4c6dcf71"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"sto8h236925","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the stretch of the hamstring is too strenuous and you cannot really reach the floor with your hands without rounding the back, you should bend your knees. Try to bend them slightly and see how far you can reach with the hands. Do not bend the knees too much, though, you still want to feel the stretch in the legs.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:42:13.362Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:42:13.362Z","id":"918447e1-dbad-4de4-acb1-c74bbdf16f9e"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Corpse Pose
Alt Text: How to do Corpse Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Corpse Pose or Savasana is a resting pose that helps relax, calm, restore and energize the whole body.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Corpse Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e01s4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start out lying on your back and rest your arms alongside the body with the palms facing upwards. Extend your legs straight out in front of you and allow your feet to drop out to the side to relax the legs completely. Close your eyes softly.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9ioc6","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Take slow deep breaths through your nose, if possible. Slowly inhale, hold the breath for a second or two, and then slowly exhale, again pause and holding the breath for a second or two – keep repeating and find a natural flow to your breath. Allow every muscle in the body to rest. Keep bringing your attention back to your body, feeling every muscle and trying to relax them.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2k186","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Start relaxing the muscles in the tips of your toes then move towards your feet and legs. Work your way up to your legs, towards your hips - and then from your lower back - up towards the upper back and back of your shoulders. - Bring your attention then back towards your hips and this time scan up the front of the body from the lower belly up towards your chest and armpits. - Allow the front of your body to melt down into the back of your body. – Then bring your attention to your fingertips and scan up both arms, keeping them heavy until you reach your shoulders again. - Drop the back of your neck down towards the ground, soften your jaw, muscles around your mouth and eyes and the space between your eyebrows. - Relax the muscles in your forehead, drop the back of the head down completely into the ground and finally bring the attention to the crown of your head, while keeping an expressionless face.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"66n0f","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. You can even go a level deeper and focus on your core and heartbeat. Keep breathing slowly and steadily.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5kc9e","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Release all control of your breath and go deeper into releasing the tension. If thoughts arise - as they probably will - keep bringing your attention towards observing your breath.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1b1a4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay in this position for about 10 minutes or whatever feels right.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aehln","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Once you are ready to come out of the pose starts to slowly bring some movement back into the body again, by wiggling your fingers and your toes. From here, roll over onto your right side and slowly come back towards a sitting position allowing your head to come up last. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:15.209Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:15.209Z","id":"3aef3e18-2296-4b2e-85f4-c1d61a69c05a"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7roni","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4tmnt","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This pose is, most of the time, performed for a longer period of time (more than 10 minutes). Because of this and the passiveness of the pose, your body will cool off. So it can be useful to keep a blanket close by, to pull over yourself once you start the pose.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"63ru2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are in a late-term pregnancy it should be better to avoid this lying position or modify it by lying on your side perhaps with a cushion or bolster between your knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:31.646Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:31.646Z","id":"225d63ba-0ceb-4101-955a-8366b0ccb4c7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1g7nj","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are uncomfortable in this lying position. You can try it out with a rolled-up blanket or firm pillow under your lower back or knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9tm3q","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have pain in your neck you can support your head with a blanket.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:47.056Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:06:47.056Z","id":"f9a18cda-6537-41be-9a0a-2b7d7fe3319d"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Warrior 1
Alt Text: How to do Warrior 1 Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Warrior 1 Pose or Virabhadrasana 1 builds strength and stability in the legs, ankles, abdomen, lower back, shoulders, and arms.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Warrior 1 Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qgw2i36318","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing tall with your arms relaxed to the sides. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"tnuf636320","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Now, take a big step back to the right and place your right foot pointing forwards and your left foot pointing out to the left side. Try to align both heels with each other. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ljxpm36322","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Twist your upper body towards your right leg, while simultaneously bending your right knee, so that your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Move your right calf muscle forward and your right knee a little out to the right side. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vi2vo36324","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. On your next inhale, raise your arms up towards the ceiling, draw your belly in and up, twisting your heart towards your right knee and lifting your chest upwards. Keep your body and your breathing stable. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ipk5e36326","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Make sure the arms are straight and reach your fingertips up towards the ceiling. You can keep your arms shoulder-width apart or if you have space bring the palms together. Bring your gaze up towards your hands. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"93z1336328","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay here for at least five long deep breaths. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4fklz36330","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. To release, bring the arms back down alongside your body and head back to a neutral position. Bring the weight forward to your right leg and step back to standing with the legs together. Repeat, with the left leg in front. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9pzgy36332","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Take a big step back to the left and place your left foot pointing forwards and your right foot pointing out to the right side. Try to align both heels with each other. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ijgqg36334","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Twist your upper body towards your left leg, while simultaneously bending your left knee, so that your left thigh is parallel to the ground. Move your left calf muscle forward and your left knee a little out to the left side. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b9q8t36336","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. On your next inhale, raise your arms up towards the ceiling, draw your belly in and up, twisting your heart towards your left knee and lifting your chest upwards. Keep your body and your breathing stable. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"h5bhi36338","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Make sure the arms are straight and reach your fingertips up towards the ceiling. Again, you can keep your arms shoulder-width apart or if you have space bring the palms together. Bring your gaze up towards your hands. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1z26i36340","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Stay here for at least five long deep breaths. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0jtr136342","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. To release, bring the arms back down alongside your body and head back to a neutral position. Bring the weight forward to your left leg and step back to standing with the legs together. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:29:39.664Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:29:39.664Z","id":"19e87151-7158-4bd6-9c94-b3ab8950fc53"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"y0ycn163776","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"yefxj164276","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Adjust the position when experiencing neck injury or pain. Keep the neck aligned with the spine of the back, so you are looking to your front instead of looking up. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"tbkcv164804","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician on whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:37:30.731Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:37:30.731Z","id":"50545d27-44c3-425f-bf80-d5560680eb36"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"jv3ys163306","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you find it difficult to keep the heel on the floor, you could keep your back heel lifted or find a steady object to rest your back heel on.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:37:50.687Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:37:50.687Z","id":"c560b0fc-aa56-4435-8a4b-8b4f12c4c8fc"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Supine Hammock Pose with Yoga Strap
Alt Text: How to do Supine Hammock Pose with Yoga Strap
Short Description: The Supine Hammock Pose with Yoga strap, or Supta Padangusthasana, is a restorative pose that targets the hamstrings and gives the neck and lower back a gentle release.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Supine Hammock Pose with Yoga strap can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4fcwg1031","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by lying down.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"juc0g1033","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Make sure the Feelix Yoga strap is completely unfurled. Run the Feelix Yoga strap through slot one on the lock and pull the strap all the way through until the lock reaches the rivet.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8512e1035","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Take the strap around the base of your neck and close the lock by threading the strap up through slot two, down through slot three.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"uuht31037","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Make sure the Yoga strap loop is as big as it can be. Bend the right knee and loop the strap over the ball of the right foot, keeping the other end of the loop around the base of the neck.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bb40v1039","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Straighten the right leg as much as possible. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"t5xnx1041","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Let the head be heavy in the strap so that the strap is supporting the neck.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7cj971043","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Let the left arm come out to the side.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sxqiq1045","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Flex the foot, making sure the second toe lines up with the middle of the ankle crease.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0uxgr1047","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. The left leg is straight. Press the leg down into the floor. Hug the muscles to the bones in the legs. Flex the foot with the toes facing up towards the sky.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5xwcj1049","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Stay for some deep breaths. This pose can be held for a minute or more.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9xq621051","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. To come out of the pose bend the right leg and remove the strap, gently releasing the head back down to the ground.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gdswz1053","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Repeat on the other side.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c16su1055","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:50:44.025Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:50:44.025Z","id":"5ba4552b-44b0-4325-8ffc-ad4bb4848d53"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"iyuz62492","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not do this pose if you have a neck injury or issues.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"j7h6z2494","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Be careful not to lock the knees","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":". Have tiny bend/s in the knee/s if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"367g62498","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"swihg2500","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:51:53.376Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:51:53.376Z","id":"16cde8ce-5cef-4619-81e2-1b79c2632f5a"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• The lifted leg can have a bend in the knee if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ay5gc3363","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Move the leg higher or lower by ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"making the strap loop smaller or bigger","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"04p1g3367","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Two straps can be used with this pose. Use one strap with the left leg that is straight along the floor. Bend the left knee and hook the strap around the ball of the foot then straighten the leg. Hold on to the strap with the left hand. Then set up the hammock strap as above.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:52:49.036Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-18T23:52:49.036Z","id":"25306bd0-9d5e-49d2-8e07-e6629b4efe60"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Thread the Needle
Alt Text: How to do Thread the Needle Yoga
Short Description: Thread-the-Needle is a calming yoga pose where one arm threads under the torso, stretching the shoulders and upper back while promoting relaxation and releasing tension. Enhances flexibility and reduces stress.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Thread-the-Needle Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"fs9gp63993","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"i3nle63994","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2ivtm63995","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees, with your wrists aligned under your shoulders and knees under your hips.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"1wz7m63997","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"dh4t263998","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Inhale deeply and, on an exhale, lift your right hand off the mat.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ixfit64000","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ln3gt64001","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Slide your right arm underneath your body and reach it across the mat to the left side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"eln8c64003","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"9wg2964004","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As you thread your arm through, lower your right shoulder and temple to the mat, allowing your right arm to extend fully.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"s9ipn64006","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"lmb5k64007","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Keep your left hand grounded firmly on the mat to maintain stability.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"mfrmq64009","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2yo5t64010","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Once in position, take a deep breath and, on each exhale, gently twist your upper body to the left, opening up your chest and shoulders.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"67tbv64012","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8ytds64013","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Ensure your hips remain squared and level throughout the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"fpfvf64015","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ftwhl64016","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hold the pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, breathing deeply and relaxing into the stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"7oeoq64018","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"z6iyx64019","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To come out of the pose, slowly release the twist and slide your right hand back to the starting position on all fours.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jwnbo64021","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"am2fa64022","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Repeat the same steps on the other side, lifting your left hand off the mat and threading it under your body to the right side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"x0fwg64024","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wknzy64037","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember to listen to your body, and if you experience any discomfort or pain, modify the pose or seek guidance from a yoga instructor. Thread-the-Needle is a gentle and restorative pose, providing a lovely stretch for the shoulders and upper back while promoting a sense of relaxation and ease.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:12:41.798Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:12:41.798Z","id":"f45dadfb-6e82-4f45-9e6f-b482a9f00b0e"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"While Thread-the-Needle is generally a safe and gentle yoga pose, there are a few contraindications and cautions to keep in mind, especially if you have specific health conditions. Here they are:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"9rdm365420","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"09i9w65421","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"hgfng65422","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent or Chronic Shoulder Injury","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Avoid this pose if you have a recent or chronic shoulder injury, such as a dislocation, impingement, or rotator cuff tear. The twisting motion could aggravate the condition.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jplaz65425","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vqyk165426","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wrist Issues","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have carpal tunnel syndrome or any wrist injury, be cautious as putting pressure on the wrists in this pose may exacerbate the problem.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"4c07r65429","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"e7kkd65430","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Pregnant women should approach this pose with caution, especially in the later stages of pregnancy. Modifications, such as using a cushion or block for support, might be necessary.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"asx9t65433","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"aarve65436","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2qsr265437","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Neck Sensitivity or Injury","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have neck issues or sensitivity, avoid putting excessive weight on the temple. Consider using a folded blanket or cushion for support.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"znef265440","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"153lp65441","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High or Low Blood Pressure","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": The mild inversion in this pose can affect blood pressure. If you have high or low blood pressure, be mindful of how your body responds and come out of the pose if you feel lightheaded or uncomfortable.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"2ju5n65444","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"qru9i65445","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lower Back Problems","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": People with lower back issues, especially those that worsen with twisting, should be cautious and may need to modify the pose or avoid it altogether.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"qny5565448","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"lxsly65449","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Knee Injury or Instability","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have knee problems, be mindful while threading the arm under the body to avoid putting excessive pressure on the knees.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ohyxs65452","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"fwp7o65471","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always listen to your body and practice mindfully. If you are uncertain about the suitability of this pose for your individual condition, it's best to consult with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional before attempting it. They can provide personalized guidance and modifications to ensure your safety and comfort during the practice.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:23:29.144Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:23:29.144Z","id":"f08ed9f8-3be5-4d87-a1c7-78b7df5b85be"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If you find that Thread-the-Needle pose is challenging or not suitable for your body, there are several alternatives and modifications you can try to achieve similar benefits or address specific concerns. Here are some options:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"7i4ro66526","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hrzch66527","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7f46j66528","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Seated Thread-the-Needle","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Instead of being in a tabletop position, sit comfortably on your mat with your legs crossed. Reach your right arm under your left arm and twist your upper body to the left, resting your right shoulder and temple on the mat. This seated variation reduces pressure on the wrists and knees.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7ry3y66532","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"4gdbm66535","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"kn3pq66536","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Threading the Needle with Chest Opener","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": In the traditional tabletop position, after threading your right arm under, extend your left arm overhead, stretching it towards the right side, and opening your chest towards the ceiling. This variation adds a gentle backbend and shoulder stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"eg8m166539","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3605366540","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supported Thread-the-Needle","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Place a folded blanket or cushion under your head and shoulder for extra support and to reduce pressure on the neck and temple. This modification can be helpful for those with neck sensitivity or injuries.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"fngex66543","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"w5ah166544","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Thread-the-Needle with Blocks","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have limited mobility or find it challenging to reach the mat with your arm, place yoga blocks under your hands. This elevates the floor, making the pose more accessible.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"wkqok66547","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"uov1q66548","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Child's Pose","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you are unable to perform Thread-the-Needle or need a restorative option, come into Child's Pose. Sit on your heels, reach your arms forward, and rest your forehead on the mat. Child's Pose gently stretches the shoulders and offers a similar sense of relaxation.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"x5lf966551","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xjsse66566","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, the goal is to find a variation that suits your body and provides the intended benefits without causing discomfort or strain. Feel free to explore these alternatives and work with a qualified yoga instructor to customize the practice according to your specific needs and abilities.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:25:30.887Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:25:30.887Z","id":"70236298-95f9-49cc-a549-ded3449cd04e"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Knees-to-Chest Pose
Alt Text: How to do Knees-to-Chest pose Yoga
Short Description: The Knees-to-Chest Pose, or Apanasana, relieves lower back pain and massages the abdominal organs – reducing bloating, stomach pain and tension in the body.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Knees-to-Chest Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7srlo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by lying on your back. Bring both knees into your chest and wrap your arms around the knees. Hug the arms close together and with the hands try to hold on to the opposite hands, elbows or forearms.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"924te","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. If you find it difficult to clasp both hands around your knees, you could bring the legs a little bit outward, so the legs don’t push as much on the belly and rest your hands on your knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4elgv","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Tuck your chin a little towards your chest, but make sure the back of your neck keeps resting against the floor. At the same time, press the tailbone and lower back to the floor and pull your legs a little closer towards the chest.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c189u","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Next, ground the shoulders into the floor, so the whole of your spine is parallel to the floor. From here you can relax your legs, feet, and hips.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"81avi","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Breathe deep into your belly, pressing up against the thighs. You can close the eyes here.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fm9r7","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. After staying for at least five, long and deep breaths, slowly release the legs and come back to lying on your back.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:36.834Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:36.834Z","id":"aa0c8e2d-0810-4ac8-b892-42a5ff41851c"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"45bkq","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"6g4b3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not practice this pose when you have injured abdominal muscles, injured or painful spine, or are recovering from a hernia, or when in pregnancy.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"fscsk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:48.554Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:48.554Z","id":"328041d3-1751-4c0c-b23c-0bb7cc7e6eef"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" • If you find it difficult to clasp both hands around your knees, you could bring the legs a little bit outward, so the legs do not push as much on the belly and rest your hands on your knees.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"6i17i","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could try the same pose with one leg at the time, so there is always one leg straightened. If your hips feel very tight, bend the straight leg and place the foot of that leg on the floor.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:12.384Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:17:12.384Z","id":"be84cc01-a011-4dfd-b533-ad01ab12df82"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Thunderbolt Pose
Alt Text: How to do Thunderbolt Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Thunderbolt Pose or Vajrasana stretches and strengthens the thighs, lower back, and legs. Additionally, facilitating digestion.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Thunderbolt Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gh98e80065","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Come onto your hands and knees. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o252580111","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. From here bring the knees together and lift your upper body so that your hips are above your knees. Bring your thumbs towards the top of your calf muscles at the back of the knee and use your thumbs to rotate your calf muscles outwards. Then lower your hips down to sit on your heels. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vxb8b80185","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Hold an upright position with your torso and allow your sitting bones to drop down heavily on your heels. If the full pose feels too intense, you can lift the hips a little by sitting on a cushion. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ahma380287","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Rest your hands on your thighs and keep lifting the insides of your knees up and grounding the tops of the toes down. Activate your abdominal muscles and draw the shoulders down while you open the front of your chest and lift it slightly up towards your chin. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vj7hb80417","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Stay in this pose for at least five breaths or maybe a little longer. Keep the gaze of your eyes looking softly down. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"szoml80575","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. To release the pose, lift your hips up and come back to your hands and knees. Here you can press the palms of the hands into the ground and one at a time extend each leg out away from you. Then come back to a sitting position with the legs outstretched. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:23:44.348Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:23:44.348Z","id":"df7edb94-4340-42d5-9c32-2617a4c04f22"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"n74yj81003","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"1qoy681248","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose if you have ankle or knee injuries. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"kljbg81521","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Watch out when you have rigid ankles or knees. With rigid ankles place a pillow or rolled-up towel underneath your feet and shins. With rigid knees place a pillow or rolled-up towel on top of your ankles, underneath your sitting bones. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"gelfv81822","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:23:54.545Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:23:54.545Z","id":"7e803fff-bf4b-4e8c-8fc7-ebbf9f6ce457"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"xcosg84153","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You can make the pose easier for the knees and ankles by using a cushion or rolled-up towel. Either placing it underneath your ankles and shins to soften the ankles or underneath the sitting bones to soften the knees.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"003qk84379","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:25:59.119Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:25:59.119Z","id":"d16108bf-dead-478a-9055-34d93fbb65dd"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Chair Pose
Alt Text: How to do Chair Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Chair Pose, or Utkatasana, works on building strength in the legs, especially the quadriceps and inner thighs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Chair Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1nn3d","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start this pose by standing tall with your feet together, big toes touching and arms relaxed by your sides. Notice if your weight is slightly towards the toes or heels. If needed adjust yourself to feel grounded in the center, keeping a slight bend in the knees. You can stay in this position a little longer, if it feels nice, before starting the chair pose.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c9p5i","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Now if you are ready, check that your legs are close together with the big toes touching.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"165bp","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Sink your hips down and back, reaching your fingertips towards the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bgc80","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. From here raise your arms up, straightening your arms and extending your fingers up towards the ceiling. If you have space in your shoulders you can bring the palms of your hands together above your head. Gaze up towards your thumbs.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7fvur","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Bring your weight back into your heels and see if you can bend your knees a little deeper, dropping the hips a little further down and back - as if you’re about to sit on a chair.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7dc1n","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep lengthening and lifting the front of your body upwards and drawing the abdomen in and up – avoiding the overarching of your back. Reach your fingertips a little higher while dropping the weight of your shoulders down away from your ears.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3lvqa","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep the abdomen and hip muscles active.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1hc2k","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Come out of the pose by pressing through the feet and come back into the standing pose that you started in.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:03:11.193Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:03:11.193Z","id":"87ff5e71-f7b5-4be3-9eb0-aa8500f4497c"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fuo5a","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bpodf","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Because this can be a physically demanding pose, it is best to avoid when feeling weak or sick, or when you are experiencing headaches, low blood pressure or insomnia.  • Watch out for sensitive knees and avoid sinking the hips down too low if you feel pain in your knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8usbm","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are uncertain, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:03:38.342Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:03:38.342Z","id":"62f5aa85-09df-4334-9085-f69d37db5d00"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"183m9","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are new to this pose or find this a hard pose it is a good idea to bring the feet hip-distance apart.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9aaot","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If uncertain about this pose you could start out placing a chair behind you while performing the pose, or instead of raising the arms over the head, start out with your hands on the hips for support.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6u1dd","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:01.852Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:01.852Z","id":"2602d9ba-69b2-40c8-b585-c5b457dc242b"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Child Pose
Alt Text: How to do Child Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Child Pose, or Balasana, stretches the ankles, thighs, hips, spine, and shoulders. Relieving tension in the back and neck, and calming the nervous system.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Child Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"24fme","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by coming onto your hands and knees. From here bring your knees a bit wider than your hips, with your big toes touching.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3tfih","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Slowly lower the torso down and allow your belly to rest between your legs.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"er8fp","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Drop the head down and let the forehead rest on the floor, releasing any tension from your face. Make sure the neck is neutral and without pressure on it.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"et86g","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Drop the hips down towards your heels, as you extend and lengthen your spine and fingertips forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"emrg3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. You can either continue to lie with your arms out in front of you or bring your arms behind you with the hands next to your feet.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4utfm","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay in this position for at least five deep breaths, or maybe much longer, if that feels right for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1p6q3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. If you are ready to come out of the pose, press your palms down and lift back up to your hands and knees.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:18.117Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:18.117Z","id":"5f6943a4-4225-4318-8a04-55d5640e8e6b"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2sh82","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2l5ck","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Keep the neck safe from injury by holding it in a neutral position.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e9qv5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this position if you have, or are recovering from, a knee injury.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2hgri","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are pregnant, make sure the legs are far enough apart, so your belly does not get pressured by the legs.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e4phj","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If there is any concern, please contact your physician on whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:38.494Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:38.494Z","id":"4ce874d7-6b5f-4c21-ad6f-ee88781a59c2"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cdi0k","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This position is all about getting rest in a comfortable and easy position. If you experience any discomfort, for example your forehead feels sore, or your ankles, please place a cushion underneath them, to make the position more comfortable.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b310j","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:52.365Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:04:52.365Z","id":"88e62654-0f95-4593-878f-65b8edd3b5af"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Upward Plank Pose
Alt Text: How to do Upward Plank Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Upward or Reverse Plank Pose or Purvottanasana opens the front of the shoulders and strengthens the wrists, arms, abdomen, and legs.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Upward Plank Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ywaje141541","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in a seated position, with your legs stretched out in front of you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n5y0e141587","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bring your hands behind the hips, with your fingertips pointing towards your feet, and place the soles of your feet on the ground. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o2r6k141664","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Spread your fingers apart and press your hands and feet into the floor, while bringing your hips and knees up in one line. Keep activating your abdomen and grounding the palms of your hands, as you lift and open the front of your shoulders. If this is difficult to hold, you can come in and out of the pose several times.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gcwpp141770","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" 4. If you feel ready, from here you can extend your legs out in front of you, pointing your toes and grounding them as much as you can towards the floor. If it feels comfortable for your neck to allow your head to drop back behind you, otherwise keep your chin tucking into the chest. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ug3p5142064","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Gaze towards your nose as you stay here for at least five, long and deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"w3z4h142222","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep the chest still lifted as you slowly drop your hips down towards the floor. Bring your neck back into a neutral position and finish back sitting with the legs out in front of you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:03.398Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:03.398Z","id":"f6f336d2-125f-40d8-9cb9-3a17b160a29b"},"documentStyle":{}}
