Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"ygmx3142523","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"o5fh0142895","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have any injuries in your shoulders or wrists, do not perform this exercise. If you are prone to injuries in your shoulders or wrists, please be extra careful. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"dygzg143179","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:26.664Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:26.664Z","id":"41128ce8-2494-46d4-bd29-9be6a1f41916"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"23cx2145419","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could keep your knees bent throughout the pose to make it lighter.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:59.455Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:36:59.455Z","id":"1cbd2051-948b-4d49-8890-c14b82a80c98"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Three-Legged Dog
Alt Text: How to do Three-Legged Dog Yoga
Short Description: Three-Legged Dog is a rejuvenating yoga pose that resembles an inverted "V" shape. It involves lifting one leg high while balancing on hands and the opposite foot, fostering strength, balance, and flexibility.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Three-Legged Dog pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"71ur768281","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"3x3jq68285","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"kn2ax68286","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"oaxn568287","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Begin in a tabletop position on your hands and knees, ensuring your wrists are directly under your shoulders and knees under your hips.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"wspz668289","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ihyew68290","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine. Spread your fingers wide, pressing firmly into the mat for stability.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"84yhb68292","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"m26pd68293","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Inhale deeply and as you exhale, lift your hips up towards the ceiling, coming into Downward Facing Dog. Straighten your legs as much as comfortable, forming an inverted \"V\" shape with your body.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"tg0vs68295","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"oucr368296","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Shift your weight slightly forward, taking some pressure off your hands, but maintaining stability in your arms.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"jxkr668298","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"45yxe68299","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"On an inhalation, lift one leg off the mat, extending it straight back and up. Keep your hips level and square to the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5bu5u68301","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"6zy4w68302","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Flex your foot to engage the leg muscles and reach through the heel for a more active stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"m0kf468304","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"uphew68305","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Maintain a steady breath and keep your shoulders relaxed, away from your ears.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"qra6u68307","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"l3jbw68308","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hold the pose for a few breaths, focusing on lengthening the lifted leg and grounding through the hands and opposite foot.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ln26h68310","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"10ri568311","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To release the pose, exhale and gently lower the lifted leg back down to the floor, returning to the Downward Facing Dog position.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"0n0qw68313","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2gcwz68314","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Take a moment to rest in Downward Dog before repeating the pose on the other side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:31:06.253Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:31:06.253Z","id":"afe1453a-f6a3-4961-a86b-37fbf8264fd2"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"While Three-Legged Dog (Three-Legged Downward Facing Dog) is generally a safe and beneficial yoga pose, there are some contraindications and cautions to consider:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"82nlz69710","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9fjtu69711","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"0au7469712","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wrist or Shoulder Injuries","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have wrist or shoulder issues, be cautious while practicing this pose. Consider using yoga props, like blocks, to decrease pressure on the wrists.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"vf0qs69715","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ol7is69716","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High Blood Pressure","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Inverted poses, including Downward Facing Dog variations, can increase blood pressure. If you have high blood pressure, be mindful of the time you spend in this pose and avoid straining.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"je37l69719","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"imb9m69720","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Carpal Tunnel Syndrome","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have carpal tunnel syndrome, you might experience discomfort in the wrists during weight-bearing poses like this. Modify the pose or avoid it if necessary.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6pswi69723","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ka07969724","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Neck Injuries","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Be careful not to strain your neck by letting it hang heavily in this pose. Keep your neck aligned with your spine.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"2rexk69727","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"y70i369728","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hamstring or Hip Flexor Injuries","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you have hamstring or hip flexor issues, be cautious when lifting your leg in Three-Legged Dog. Avoid overstretching and only go as far as your body allows without pain.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"tbqu569731","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mubno69732","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": For pregnant individuals, this pose might not be suitable, especially as the pregnancy progresses, due to the inversion and the pressure on the abdomen.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"dfpko69735","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8kq4369736","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Vertigo or Dizziness","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Inverted poses can trigger or worsen feelings of dizziness or vertigo. If you experience these sensations, it's best to avoid this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6uad769739","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"9e6oe69740","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent Surgery or Injury","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If you've recently had surgery or have an injury, consult with a healthcare professional or a qualified yoga instructor before attempting Three-Legged Dog.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"usr2c69743","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"noies69744","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High Blood Pressure","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Inverted poses can elevate blood pressure, so people with uncontrolled high blood pressure should avoid this pose or practice it with great caution.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ippjq69747","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zymjk69768","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As with any yoga pose, it's essential to listen to your body, avoid pushing yourself beyond your limits, and seek guidance from a yoga instructor, especially if you're new to the pose or have any specific health concerns. Always inform your instructor about any injuries or medical conditions before starting a yoga practice. They can provide appropriate modifications or alternatives to keep your practice safe and enjoyable.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:32:47.787Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:32:47.787Z","id":"8af7a9ae-e795-4fa5-87cd-98721870e1ae"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If you have contraindications or concerns about practicing Three-Legged Dog (Three-Legged Downward Facing Dog), there are several options and alternative poses you can explore:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"rckra72524","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5okq172411","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jmqbq72412","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Downward Facing Dog","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": If lifting one leg feels challenging, you can practice the regular Downward Facing Dog pose. This variation is still highly beneficial for strengthening and stretching the body.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"caqwj72415","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ypf8x72416","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Modified Downward Facing Dog","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Place your hands on a sturdy chair, a wall, or use yoga blocks under your hands. This modification reduces the weight on your upper body, making it suitable for those with wrist issues or limited upper body strength.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"aj41r72419","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5o4qq72420","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Puppy Pose (Anahatasana)","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": This gentle heart-opening pose is a great alternative for people with wrist or shoulder issues or those looking to focus more on stretching the chest and shoulders.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"vr8n072423","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mk0td72424","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Standing Forward Fold (Uttanasana)","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": This standing pose provides a mild inversion and is an excellent alternative for people with high blood pressure or who prefer to avoid weight-bearing on the hands.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"9q01l72427","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jppiu72428","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall Dog","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Face a wall and place your hands shoulder-width apart on the wall at chest height. Walk your feet back and your body at a 45-degree angle to the wall, creating a modified version of Downward Facing Dog.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"m7sfi72431","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"tjqcz72432","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Supported Bridge Pose","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Lie on your back with your feet flat on the floor and knees bent. Lift your hips and place a yoga block or cushion under your sacrum for a gentle inversion.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"0hg8r72435","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"19pts72436","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Legs Up the Wall (Viparita Karani)","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Lie on your back with your legs resting against a wall, creating a relaxing and gentle inversion that can help alleviate tired legs and improve circulation.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"1p1ph72439","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mrz7072440","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cat-Cow Stretch","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":": Focus on gentle spinal movements in Cat-Cow instead of holding inverted poses. This is suitable for warming up the spine and improving flexibility.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ghwtl72443","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember that every yoga practice can be tailored to individual needs and limitations. If you're unsure about which alternative is best for you, consider consulting with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific conditions and goals.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:47:22.122Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:47:22.122Z","id":"5b5e5025-4a62-486d-b6cd-4303ab9fa8fb"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Shoulder Stand
Alt Text: How to do Shoulder Stand Yoga
Short Description: The Shoulder Stand Pose or Sarvangasana stretches the shoulders and neck, strengthening the legs and core. It can also calm the mind by reversed blood flow.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Shoulder Stand Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ja2fy5786","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin lying flat on your back with the arms alongside the body. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gi7eo5832","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Turn your palms to face downwards and engage the abdomen as you start to lift the legs up from the ground. Extend the toes towards the ceiling, but keep the hips on the ground. If possible keep your legs straight and use the strength of the abdomen to lift the legs up. Otherwise, bend your knees slightly. If it does not feel appropriate to come further, you can stay here. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"edrsk5906","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Turn your palms to face downwards and engage the abdomen as you start to lift the legs up from the ground. Extend the toes towards the ceiling, but keep the hips on the ground. If possible keep your legs straight and use the strength of the abdomen to lift the legs up. Otherwise, bend your knees slightly. If it does not feel appropriate to come further, you can stay here. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2w9ub6008","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Support either your lower or upper back with your hands, and keep the back of your neck and head on the floor. So your elbows and shoulders are firmly resting on the ground, and most of the weight is in your shoulders rather than the neck. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ezpwp6138","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Now bring your attention towards your legs, activating your leg muscles and reaching your feet up towards the ceiling. By pointing the toes it might be easier to activate your legs. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"10jzm6296","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. There is a natural tendency for the feet to reach a bit too far towards your head. To resist this, reach your feet back so that your ankles, hips, and shoulders are in one line. The abdomen needs to strongly engage to support you here. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8xwnq6482","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep your gaze looking towards your big toes, as you stay here for between five and ten breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"koelg6696","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Slowly come out of the pose by releasing the support on your back and rolling down, vertebrae by vertebrae, your upper, middle and lower back to the ground. Once the hips connect with the floor, you can use the strength of your abdomen to slowly and with control lower the legs back down to the floor, returning back to lying on your back with arms alongside your body. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:53:49.334Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:53:49.334Z","id":"2b51f91a-5b36-4ff1-9c7e-a60a681d490c"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"3c6py7242","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have any neck or shoulder injury please do not perform this pose. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"ivlgo7543","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• It is advised for women to avoid staying too long in this pose if you are on the first couple of days of your period. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"935bz7872","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If there is any concern, please contact your physician for advice on whether or not this position is beneficial to you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"rtra98229","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Once you are in the pose avoid moving your neck and looking to the side as this will bring too much pressure onto your neck. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"qaqhi8614","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:54:10.845Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:54:10.845Z","id":"016274e9-e124-4e23-87dc-2079d9321c2d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Keep the hips connected to the ground and extend the legs up straight towards the ceiling. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"wtbpq11178","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• For a more gentle version, you can keep the hips on the ground still and rest the legs against a wall.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:56:04.809Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:56:04.809Z","id":"efb72989-794f-48d6-b096-a1421674c7c6"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Mountain Pose
Alt Text: How to do Mountain Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Mountain Pose, or Tadasana, helps create awareness of your muscles and balance and increases strength and flexibility in the feet, legs, and hips. Even though this pose is very basic and seems easy, it is not less important. This pose is just as important as other poses and good to increase body/muscle awareness.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Mountain Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"44gtm","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start standing up, feet hip-width apart, or come to stand with your big toes touching and heels slightly apart. Spread your toes wide apart.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6ktrc","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Stand tall with your legs, but avoid locking your knees. Bring your attention towards the various muscles in the calf, the front upper leg, the back upper leg, and your buttocks. Feel the muscles in your inner thighs and bring your knees a little outward, but do not overdo it. Make sure your muscles are relaxed and engaged by distributing the weight over the muscles.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"eqtjv","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Try to hold the form in your legs, while slowly directing your attention to your torso. Make sure the spine is upright and neutral. Let your abdominal muscles and lower back muscles engage to help stay in an upright position, not squeezing them too much, but just noticing them and making minor adjustments, if needed.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fv0oe","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Take comfortable long breaths in and out through the nose, while still keeping the same posture in your legs, abdominals and lower back.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"borjp","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. From here roll your shoulders up and back, drawing the front of your armpits back. Soften the shoulder muscles at the top of your arms and let your arms hang low along your body, with your hands at your sides. At the same time bring your chest a little up and forward, until you find a comfortable position.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b24sr","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Finally give special attention to your neck, tucking your chin a little into your chest making sure your neck is nicely aligned with your spine.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"90ush","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep your gaze looking slightly down, as you deepen your breath and keep your focus on simultaneously relaxing and engaging all your muscles.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aiq63","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Overall you want to find an active posture that comes naturally to your body, giving a corrective effect and bringing relaxation.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5a9so","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Stay in this pose for at least five long deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5rjf7","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Moving out of the pose whenever you feel ready. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:26:49.689Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:26:49.689Z","id":"49796ec2-b2f5-4a84-b27f-23e64595ca5a"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"2as1s","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"ac7lj","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This position asks for balance. It is important you are not experiencing any low blood pressure, dizziness or nausea before practicing this position.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"bhfuo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:09.417Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:09.417Z","id":"5e851c5b-9651-491b-8b9b-38589135d791"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"febp3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Start this position with your feet hip-width apart if you are new to the mountain position.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"bpnjo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you find it difficult to keep focus, it can be beneficial to close your eyes while performing the pose, your body will search for balance, and if you keep the eyes closed you will feel the muscles more deeply.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:24.941Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:24.941Z","id":"d5365ab4-44cf-47f8-ade9-7d6a83829826"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Pyramid Pose
Alt Text: How to do Pyramid Pose Yoga Parsvottanasana
Short Description: Pyramid Pose, also known as Parsvottanasana, is a rejuvenating standing yoga posture that offers a host of physical and mental benefits.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pyramid Pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"xrd0m43536","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"qh8ryhnqvgo1ne43453","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fdx8p37524","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Start by standing at the top of your yoga mat with your feet together and arms at your sides, in Tadasana (Mountain Pose).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"05zpwhnqvgo1ne43455","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qy7k737527","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Take a moment to ground yourself and find your balance, distributing your weight evenly between both feet.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hf434hnqvgo1ne43457","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1q3p937530","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Step your right foot back about 3 to 4 feet (around one leg-length) behind your left foot. Ensure that your hips are squared to the front of the mat.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"uc36ohnqvgo1ne43459","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"efab337533","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Turn your back foot out at a 45-degree angle, so the toes are pointing towards the back corner of the mat. The back heel should be grounded firmly.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"1kardhnqvgo1ne43461","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"80n9037536","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"With an inhale, engage your core and lengthen your spine, lifting your chest slightly.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"4wyp4hnqvgo1ne43463","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"lfoax37539","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As you exhale, begin to hinge at the hips and fold forward, leading with your chest. Keep your back flat and avoid rounding the spine.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"0t7kyhnqvgo1ne43465","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b6ohl37542","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bring your hands to the hips or interlace your fingers behind your back, stretching your arms toward the ground. If your hands are clasped, keep your arms straight and work on rolling your shoulders back to open the chest.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"5powuhnqvgo1ne43467","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"uibyf37545","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Continue to fold deeper into the pose with each breath, but remember to maintain length in the spine.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"c54ljhnqvgo1ne43469","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"xmtz137548","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Keep your front leg straight and strong, pressing through the heel to activate the quadriceps.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6hcqkhnqvgo1ne43471","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2utft37551","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If your hamstrings are tight, you can slightly bend your front knee to avoid strain.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ujeughnqvgo1ne43473","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dilxs37554","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hold the pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, breathing deeply and maintaining focus on your breath.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"wntsphnqvgo1ne43475","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"u53eu37557","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To release the pose, with an inhale, lift your chest and come back up to a standing position.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"8mqwkhnqvgo1ne43477","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"wzcvv37560","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Step your right foot forward to meet the left and return to Tadasana.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"zc1kvhnqvgo1ne43479","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c50yk37563","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Repeat the same steps on the other side, stepping your left foot back and folding over the left leg.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:19:39.569Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T05:19:39.569Z","id":"e46f315b-2d9a-4a35-baa3-c4b2ee994196"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"j84za39100","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"j0v7h39101","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pew3338976","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High blood pressure: Pyramid Pose involves a forward fold, which may increase blood pressure in the head. Individuals with uncontrolled high blood pressure or hypertension should avoid this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"pd54z39103","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"prt4j38979","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Heart conditions: If you have a heart condition or heart-related issues, consult with a healthcare professional or yoga instructor before attempting this pose. The intense stretch and forward fold can put strain on the cardiovascular system.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ir0my39105","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"hhjrk38982","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Spinal injuries: People with severe back issues, such as herniated discs or sciatica, should avoid or modify this pose to avoid exacerbating their condition.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"0qxuy39107","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zlexu38985","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hip injuries: Those with hip injuries or conditions like hip arthritis should use caution and modify the pose as needed to avoid discomfort or strain.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"bq6pl39109","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mrq5q38988","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy: Pregnant women should approach this pose with caution, especially in the later stages of pregnancy when balance may be affected. It's best to practice with the guidance of a qualified prenatal yoga instructor.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"1i53q38990","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6wu3p39112","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"memye38994","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hamstring injuries: Be cautious if you have a hamstring injury, as this pose can put significant strain on the hamstrings. Avoid pushing too deeply into the stretch and consider using props or bending the front knee slightly.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"b3hdv39114","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zj66s38997","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Balance issues: Pyramid Pose requires good balance, so individuals with balance issues or vertigo should practice near a wall or with the support of a chair.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"v531639116","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3vpcw39000","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Neck problems: Avoid straining the neck by keeping it aligned with the spine during the pose. Avoid looking up or down excessively.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"6ypgg39118","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7v6lz39003","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Low blood pressure: If you have low blood pressure, be cautious when coming up from the forward fold, as it may cause dizziness. Rise slowly and mindfully.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2bnq439005","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"qwpop39144","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5jjn339157","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As with any yoga practice, it's essential to listen to your body and modify or skip poses that may not be suitable for your individual circumstances. If you have any concerns about your ability to practice Parsvottanasana safely, consult with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional before attempting the pose. They can help you modify the posture or suggest alternatives that suit your needs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T03:44:09.148Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T03:44:09.148Z","id":"23548967-a611-4638-9824-716479291c39"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"uhtwj40835","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"2983940747","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"o9gs440748","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Blocks or Props:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If you have tight hamstrings or difficulty reaching the floor, place yoga blocks or a stack of books under your hands. This will raise the ground closer to you, making the pose more accessible.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"2c40740751","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"lm0do40752","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bent Front Knee:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Instead of keeping the front leg straight, you can slightly bend the knee. This modification eases the stretch on the hamstrings and allows you to focus on aligning the spine.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"okec840755","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5cxo040756","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hands on Hips:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If clasping your hands behind your back feels challenging or uncomfortable, rest your hands on your hips. This provides support and helps maintain balance.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"56xql40759","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"kecev40760","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hands on Thighs:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" If folding forward feels too intense, you can place your hands on your front thigh instead of reaching for the floor. This reduces the intensity of the stretch while still engaging the legs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"kxeab40763","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mat2d40764","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall Support:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Practice the pose with your back against a wall. The wall will provide support, help you maintain balance, and prevent you from overextending the spine.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"gapvr40767","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vxfle40768","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Dynamic Movement:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Incorporate dynamic movement by gently swaying from side to side or pulsing in and out of the pose. This can help release tension and gradually deepen the stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"l09lb40771","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jqsyx40772","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Warrior 1 to Pyramid Transition:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Start in Warrior 1 pose with your right foot forward. From there, transition into Pyramid Pose by straightening your front leg and folding forward over the right leg. This allows you to flow between the two poses while maintaining stability.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"1vr8d40775","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"j5u3w40776","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Chair Variation:","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Perform a seated version of Pyramid Pose by sitting on a chair with your feet hip-width apart. Extend one leg straight out in front of you and gently fold forward from the hips, keeping the spine straight. This is a gentler option for individuals with balance issues or mobility challenges.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5gq6f40798","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"hmt9m40779","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"bsxhq40833","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, yoga is a personal practice, and it's crucial to listen to your body. Choose the modification or alternative that suits your current abilities and avoid pushing yourself into discomfort or pain. If you're unsure about which variation is best for you, consult with a certified yoga instructor who can provide personalized guidance and adjustments based on your individual needs.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T03:53:18.408Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T03:53:18.408Z","id":"0d340eaa-31e6-42d4-8427-f1811bc82bf9"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Eagle Pose
Alt Text: How to do Eagle Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Eagle Pose, or Garudasana, stretches and strengthens the ankles, legs, shoulders and upper back. It also improves balance and concentration.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Eagle Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3jqt4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start standing tall and arms relaxed alongside the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bcdf0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Bend the knees slightly and bring your right leg on top of your left leg. Bend the knees a little further and start to wrap your right leg around the left leg. Hug the inner thighs towards each other and, if you feel stable, wrap your right foot behind the left calf. If this does not feel possible keep your right big toe grounding into the floor.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bhtlo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Now extend the arms out to the sides and bring your left elbow on top of your right elbow. Bend the elbows and point the forearms upwards. Wrap the arms and hands together so that both palms of the hands are facing each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9bbmf","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. It does not matter so much whether the palms of your hands are touching each other or if your fingertips touch the hand palms. It is more important that you stay balanced and focused, as you hold this position and keep breathing steadily.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9jal7","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. If you have space, start to lift your elbows up to the same height as your shoulders and reach your hands away from your face.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4f0hi","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay here for at least five breaths, keeping your gaze looking softly forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cslqo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. When you are ready, you can release the position by unwrapping the arms and legs and come back to the same standing position in which you started. From here move to the opposite side.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fisv0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Bend the knees again slightly and bring your left leg on top of your right leg. Bend the knees a little further and start to wrap your left leg around the right leg. Hug the inner thighs towards each other and, if you feel stable, wrap your left foot behind the right calf. If this doesn’t feel possible keep your left big toe grounding into the floor.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"141n8","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Now extend the arms out to the sides and bring your right elbow on top of your left elbow. Bend the elbows and point the forearms upwards. Wrap the arms and hands together so that both palms of the hands are facing each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9fbl0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. If you have space, start to lift your elbows up to the same height as your shoulders and reach your hands away from your face.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8qd2o","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Stay here for at least five breaths, keeping your gaze looking softly forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"507gg","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. When you are ready you can release the position by unwrapping the arms and legs and come back to the same standing position in which you started. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:53:12.390Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T01:53:12.390Z","id":"0d7e8016-0d72-4b47-b843-79e020eb17f7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"1ajo7","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This position requires a lot of your balance, so avoid this pose if you’re experiencing things like headaches, low blood pressure or dizziness.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"2bkcn","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose when you’re in late-term pregnancy.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"b6dem","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not wrap the arms in this position when you’re experiencing a shoulder injury.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"5446p","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:09:45.862Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:09:45.862Z","id":"fef85ed4-e291-473c-bc8b-d1741294e02b"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"f698j","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you cannot find the balance yet, you can make it easier by not fully crossing the legs, but instead place the big toe of the top-crossing leg on the floor.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"7tgfm","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are having difficulties with the wrapping of the arms and hands, instead of trying to face the hand palms towards each other, you can let the back of the other hands face each other. This way it will be easier on your shoulder.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"anhv9","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could also try first practicing the crossing of the arms and legs separately and then  trying both at the same time.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:03.822Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:03.822Z","id":"fc715f68-fe46-4511-924b-31a30a84c729"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Happy Baby
Alt Text: How to do Happy Baby Pose Yoga
Short Description: Happy Baby (Ananda Balasana) is a relaxing yoga pose where you lie on your back, holding your feet, and gently rock from side-to-side.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Happy Baby pose can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5pltk20002","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Bend your knees towards your chest, keeping your feet off the ground.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"smuwl20007","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Hold the outer edges of your feet with your hands, or use a yoga strap around your feet if needed.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ebmo320009","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. If comfortable, gently rock side to side, enjoying the soothing stretch.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"m062t20017","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Breathe deeply and hold the pose for several breaths or as long as desired.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n2p0n20019","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Straighten your legs and relax on your back for a moment, feeling the effects of the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:53:36.361Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T01:53:36.361Z","id":"8957e151-ffd0-4200-a34c-e8bea7c2ae24"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Bound Side Angle Pose with Yoga Strap
Alt Text: How to do Bound Side Angle Pose with Yoga Strap
Short Description: Bound Side Angle Pose, or Baddha Utthita Parsvakonasana, is a standing pose that stretches the lower back and side body, opens the chest and the shoulders, and strengthens the legs and the core.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bound Side Angle","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" Pose with Yoga strap can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"13gmf39188","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing upright with the arms alongside the body. Have the Yoga strap in the left hand.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5dvn139190","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Take a big step back with your ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"left","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" leg and point your right foot forward and left foot out to the left side. Try to align your heels. Press into the outside edge of the left foot, but keep the feet flat on the ground.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8b1n739194","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. From here, start to bend your right knee deeply, so that your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your knee is lined up with your ankle. Open your right knee and right hip to the right side a little, so the knee lines up with the second big toe on the right foot, while keeping your left leg as straight as possible and opening your left hip out to the left side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"c8h3h39196","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bring your right forearm to rest lightly on your right thigh","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"phwx739200","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Peel back the left shoulder and bring the straight left arm over the ear, so you are creating a straight line from the outside edge of the back foot right to the finger tips.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xr15f39202","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. To use the strap for a bind, turn the left thumb towards the back heel, bend the elbow and bring the hand holding the strap behind the back.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"riu3239204","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Bring the right arm underneath the front right leg from the inside of the leg. The right hand then takes hold of the strap. Walk the hands along the strap towards each other. (If the hands reach, then drop the strap and just join the hands.)","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"6gcny39206","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Stay here for at least five steady and deep breaths.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"hm8oj39208","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. When you are ready to come out, release your bind, straighten your right leg, press down through your feet and step back to the front with both feet together.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"lynll39210","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Change sides and repeat the pose on the left side.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:47:47.927Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:47:47.927Z","id":"2761dcbf-7425-4244-8a47-286707d02f35"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5uity39217","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Be careful not to let the right bent knee bend too far so it comes over the ankle. This puts too much pressure on the knee.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wsxgi39221","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the bind is too uncomfortable for the shoulders, leave the forearm on the right thigh and have the left hand on the hip to modify.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"cgwcr39223","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"6s1dm39225","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mnew539230","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:48:34.517Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:48:34.517Z","id":"dbdd87b5-f5e7-4eda-b810-6fb2c06db013"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do the pose with the right forearm on the thigh and the left arm over the ear for a less intense version of this pose (without the bind).","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"j1gl939233","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Move the hands towards each other or away from each other on the strap to increase or decrease intensity.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3oz0439237","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Step the back foot closer in towards the front foot for a less intense version of this pose.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:49:00.149Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:49:00.149Z","id":"a31343ef-b30b-4d17-b2a6-5adff4dbfb08"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Cow Face Pose
Alt Text: How to do Cow Face Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Cow Face Pose or Gomukhasana stretches the hips, thighs, ankles, chest, shoulders, and arms.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Cow Face Pose can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o8vd420316","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in a seated position with your legs stretched out in front of you. Bring your right knee on top of the left knee and extend your right foot out to the left side. If you have space in your hips you can then bend your left leg underneath your right leg, bringing your left heel towards your right buttock muscle. If you notice your right hip is lifting away from the ground keep your left leg extended outwards. Over time of repeating this, your hips will start to open and the full expression of the pose will become available. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"12rfi20868","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Reach both arms up towards the ceiling and then start to bend your right arm bringing your right palm between the back of your shoulder blades. Adjust the right elbow with your left arm, opening the front of your right shoulder. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9dhzx21144","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Either stay here or reach your left arm to the left side with your thumb pointing down and then bring your left arm behind your back. If you have space slowly crawl your left arm up towards your right arm bringing the hands together if possible – otherwise grabbing the back of your t-shirt with your hands. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"755rr21448","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep opening the front of your right shoulder, lengthening and lifting your abdomen upwards and making sure that your lower ribs are not sticking out. Keep a soft gaze looking down in front of you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2b01221757","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Hold this pose for at least five long and deep breathes, perhaps for several minutes. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pawrs22117","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. To come out of the pose release your arms down and change sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"m44ew22505","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. This time bring your left knee on top of the right knee and extend your left foot out to the right side. If you have space in your hips you can then bend your right leg underneath your left leg, bringing your right heel towards your left buttock muscle. Again, if you notice your left hip is lifting away from the ground, keep your right leg extended outwards. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cqaxa22921","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Reach both arms up towards the ceiling and then start to bend your left arm, bringing your left palm between the back of your shoulder blades. Adjust the left elbow with your right arm, opening the front of your left shoulder. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6xhl823365","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Either stay here or reach your right arm to the right side with your thumb pointing down and then bring your right arm behind your back. If you have space, slowly crawl your right arm up towards your left arm bringing the hands together if possible – otherwise grabbing the back of your t-shirt with your hands. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"f4n6i23837","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Keep opening the front of your left shoulder, lengthening and lifting your abdomen upwards and making sure that your lower ribs are not sticking out. Keep a soft gaze looking down in front of you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"m4iyu24337","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Again, hold the pose for at least five long and deep breathes, and perhaps for several minutes. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fce0625222","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. When you are ready to come out of the pose let go of your hands and slowly place your arms next to the body. Finally, uncross your legs and come back into the seated position in which you started.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:03.536Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:03.536Z","id":"ec6bafa0-4d5d-4c7b-a4ed-a2d0c6d5cde8"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cakt1","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5c189","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This can be a very intense pose for the knees and shoulders. Make sure you do not have injuries or tight/weak shoulders or knees.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"40epk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything of this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:25.657Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:25.657Z","id":"9bd88dd8-1de9-4618-b1bf-c3bbbf686bac"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dqa84","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• It is important to keep an upright posture and that both your sitting bones are grounded. If you find it hard to keep an upright posture, you can extend the bottom leg out in front of you or sit upon a cushion, so that both sitting bones can ground. This will make the seated pose easier. Over time of repeating this, your hips will start to open and the full expression of the pose will become available.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9csqg","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are not able to hold the hands behind your back, you can take hold of the back of your t-shirt or use a towel in the hand of the upper arm and hold it behind the back on both sides. Each time you perform the cow face pose try to get both hands a little closer together by crawling your hands up and down the t-shirt or towel. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:38.227Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:07:38.227Z","id":"a25c771f-8b95-4a03-8462-e29e8b52187e"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Goddess Pose
Alt Text: How to do Goddess Pose Yoga
Short Description: Goddess Pose (Utkata Konasana) is a standing pose meaning powerful or fierce angle posture that symbolizes the power and strength of feminine energy, and engages and opens the hips, the front of the shoulders and the chest.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Goddess Pose","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2voa6970","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin standing in Mountain Pose","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"uusok973","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2.
