Take the feet out about half a metre apart.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xfyid975","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":". ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bend the knees.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"fy49s979","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Turn the toes out making sure the bent knees track over the toes.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"0od0j981","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Straighten the spine, sending the tailbone down towards the ground. Engage the core by drawing the lower abdominals in and up towards the heart.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"69ls7983","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Sink deeper. Try to get the thighs parallel with the ground. Push the hips down when exhaling.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"uoat4985","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Raise the arms, and take them out wide from the shoulders, bending at the elbows and pointing fingers up towards the sky (arms like a cactus).","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"rdeqr987","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Stay for six deep breaths.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-20T03:15:10.431Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-20T03:15:10.431Z","id":"4045136c-70a1-4955-b505-0d551358d9c7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"qkbwe1053","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Make sure the knees track over the toes in this pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"k3eqj1055","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Make sure you warm up for this deep hip opener by opening the hips in other ways.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"u2l511057","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"usfdv1059","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-20T03:15:10.632Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-20T03:15:10.632Z","id":"219089da-6e5c-4f08-b424-664e609bdfa8"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Try coming onto the balls of the feet and lifting the heels, or try lifting one heel at a time.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ijna24056","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Bend the knees less for less intensity.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-20T05:36:10.987Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-20T05:36:10.987Z","id":"cfba7245-52cc-436b-bd5e-989e7777625b"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Half Moon Pose
Alt Text: How to do Half Moon Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Half Moon Pose, or Ardha Chandrasana, strengthens the legs and core, trains balance, while also improving balance, coordination, and concentration.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Half Moon Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"83ekn","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing upright with the arms relaxed alongside the body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bb34s","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Now take a big step back to the right and place your right foot pointing forwards and your left foot pointing out to the left side. Try to align both heels with each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8cnm3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Reach both arms out to the side and then bend your right knee deeply. Place your right hand on the outside of your right leg and left hand to the left hip. If you cannot easily touch the ground, place something under your right hand.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"71npu","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. From here slide your right hand forward and a little to the right, as you shift your weight forward into your right leg - extending the torso forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e7u74","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Extend and straighten your right standing leg, while you lift your left leg as far as you can up from the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c8isk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stack your left hip on top of the right and reach your left heel back away from you. Try to keep your left leg as straight as possible.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"d9j3f","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. If you feel stable you can extend your left arm up towards the ceiling, and gently turn your head up looking to your left fingers. If this is too much, keep your left hand on your hip and gaze down.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3rd1q","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Keep reaching your arms and legs away from each other and breathe steadily.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"c1kj0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. If you can, stay for at least five long deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e7ve2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. To come out of the pose, lower your left leg down and shift the weight back to both legs, stepping back to the standing position that you started in. From here change sides and repeat with your left leg.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3qb4s","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. This time take a big step back to the left and place your left foot pointing forwards and your right foot pointing out to the right side. Again, try to align both heels with each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"de43i","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Reach both arms out to the side and then bend your left knee deeply. Place your left hand on the outside of your left leg and right hand to the right hip. Like on the right side, if you cannot easily touch the ground, place something under your left hand.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8pero","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. From here, slide your left hand forward and a little to the left, as you shift your weight forward into your left leg - extending the torso forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1mkt2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"14. Extend and straighten your left standing leg, while you lift your right leg, as far as you can, up from the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9pu3c","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"15. Stack your right hip on top of the left and reach your right heel back away from you. Try to keep your right leg as straight as possible.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"535t1","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"16. If you feel stable, you can extend your right arm up towards the ceiling, and gently turn your head up looking to your right fingers. If this is too much, keep your right hand on your hip and gaze down.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ddrc8","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"17. Keep reaching your arms and legs away from each other and breathe steadily.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"80oqg","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"18. If you can stay for at least five long deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"akecn","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"19. To come out of the pose, lower your right leg down and shift the weight back to both legs, then step back to the standing position that you started in. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:15:47.065Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:15:47.065Z","id":"d9b443df-9889-4689-bf25-d0cc3fb34dae"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"99j7n","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"b5lqa","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This pose requires a lot of your balance, so avoid this pose if you’re experiencing things like headaches, low blood pressure or dizziness.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"etbgj","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Avoid turning the head up when you have a neck injury.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"7nbc6","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Avoid locking the knee in this position.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"cq0lf","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:00.968Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:00.968Z","id":"07ac1670-ce9c-4fb7-bc6f-03a9459d86d1"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"cq0lf","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"fcdf1","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If it is hard to balance, you can use a block or small and steady object, like a book, to place your hand on, instead of placing it on the floor.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"2p0q4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You can also use a wall as support by either placing the foot that is in the air against it or performing the position slightly leaning against the wall.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:25.671Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:16:25.671Z","id":"fc5904fe-c4a7-4863-bd14-6f863b77109c"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Tree Pose
Alt Text: How to do Tree Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Tree Pose or Vrikshasana helps train balance and focus while strengthening the inside and outside of the legs, ankles, and tones the abdomen.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Tree Pose or Vrikshasana can be done by: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"st0ic94983","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by standing tall with your arms relaxed by your sides. Spread your toes apart and bring your weight towards the middle of your feet. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0bzpl95029","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Activate your left leg, keeping a slight bend in the knee and begin to shift your weight towards your left leg. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"l8e9o95103","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Keep gazing to a point in front of you as you make your right leg light, lifting the heel up and just balancing on your right big toe. Depending on how balanced you feel you can choose where to place your right foot, either on top of the left foot, against your left leg below your knee or with the help of your hands above your left knee. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6kf6d95205","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Keep activating your left leg and ground through your left big toe, as you press your right foot against the inside of your left leg, and at the same time press your left leg back against your right foot. Draw the right knee back to open the right hip. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"d670j95335","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. From here, place the hands first in front of your heart and then, on the next inhale, extend your arms up towards the ceiling, spreading your arms apart. Lift and lengthen your torso, finding a lift also in your lower belly. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7vf7995493","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep an active upper posture, where you reach your chest a little forward and up, straightening your arms and reaching your fingertips up towards the ceiling. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"p49r595679","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep the gaze of your eyes looking down and try to stay focussed and calm, while standing in this position. If you want to challenge your balance, you can even close your eyes. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"69ejt95901","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Stay here for at least five long breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zj8y396143","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. To release the pose, bring the palms back together in front of your heart and then place your right foot down next to your left. Change and repeat for the other leg. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"iqp9496413","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"10. Now activate your right leg, keeping a slight bend in the knee and begin to shift your weight towards your right leg this time. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"779b496711","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"11. Keep gazing to a point in front of you, as you make your left leg light, lifting the heel up and just balancing on your right big toe. Place your left foot in the same position against the right leg, as you did on the opposite side. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9d8op97049","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"12. Keep activating your right leg and ground through your right big toe, as you press your left foot against the inside of your right leg, and at the same time press your right leg back against your left foot. Draw the left knee back to open the left hip. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hd8bd97403","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"13. From here place the hands first in front of your heart and then, on the next inhale, extend your arms up towards the ceiling, spreading your arms apart. Lift and lengthen your torso, finding a lift also in your lower belly. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"serj797785","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"14. Keep an active upper posture, where you reach your chest a little forward and up, straightening your arms and reaching your fingertips up towards the ceiling. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"897zh99035","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"15. Keep the gaze of your eyes looking down and try to stay focussed and calm, while standing in this position. If you want to challenge your balance you can again close your eyes. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"f0xr299473","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"16. Stay here for at least five long, deep breaths. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4im8p99939","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"17. To release the pose, bring the palms back together in front of your heart and then place your left foot down, next to your right. Coming back to standing with your arms along your sides. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:26:15.904Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:26:15.904Z","id":"6b4e1201-f07a-47f0-85cb-6617a43a2ce7"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"8v536101036","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"3o4i0101589","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Because this can be a challenging exercise for your balance, make sure you are not experiencing headaches or dizziness. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"vr2mk102170","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:12.444Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:12.444Z","id":"a08dbc6f-32a1-454a-a11c-a714234a6366"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"2zijp104576","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have a difficult time resting your foot on the opposite leg’s inner thigh, place the foot below the knee or simply place one foot on top of the other foot.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)","foreground":"rgb(15, 15, 15)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:32.148Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T03:31:32.148Z","id":"e9c71ce1-a42e-4c79-b77b-a288185ed32d"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Cobra Pose
Alt Text: How to do Cobra Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Cobra Pose or Bhujangasana works on opening the upper back and strengthening the lower back.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Cobra Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8soch","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin by lying on your belly and extend your legs out behind you with the tops of your feet connected to the ground.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"di47c","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Place your hands under your shoulders, drawing your elbows in close to your body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ctgsn","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Activate your legs, extending your toes back away from you and pressing the tops of your feet into the ground. Lift your chest and head forward and up, while drawing the abdomen firmly in and keeping the lower ribs on the floor. Keep your elbows close to your body, opening the front of the chest and drawing your shoulders down and back. Use the strength of your lower back to lift up instead of your arms. You can even hover the palms of your hands for a moment above the ground to make sure they are not working.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4rpk2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Now, you can either repeat this fluid motion of lifting down and up a couple of times or choose to come a little further into the opening of the chest.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"drb7m","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. To come further, keep spreading your fingers apart as you push slowly but steadily through the arms and lift the chest and head up a little more, allowing the lower ribs to come off the floor. If you do not have pain in your neck, you can look up towards the ceiling, keeping the neck long and chest open; otherwise, just keep looking forward or slightly down.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a2j3k","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Keep listening well to your body, and do not go past what feels naturally good.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fkvtp","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep the eyes gazing either upwards or towards your nose and stay here for at least five steady breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5ruj8","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. To come out of the pose lower your body down slowly lower down onto your belly, resting the head on the ground. \n\n","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:11.786Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:11.786Z","id":"b22efbdb-3051-477a-9110-fd1ffd305a79"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fqh0c","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ali05","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose if you have a back or wrist injury.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6err8","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are in late-pregnancy avoid this pose.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6ruoi","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:28.972Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:28.972Z","id":"b7b01f3b-6efa-4956-9b99-14d899313169"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6vmld","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could place your elbows on the floor in front of you, arms parallel to come into a more gentle pose (Sphinx Pose).  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1huhp","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Another way to make the pose easier is by not bringing the lower ribs off the floor.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:41.188Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:05:41.188Z","id":"8f257602-5178-4b64-bc84-868865fe0683"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Fish Pose
Alt Text: How to do Fish Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Fish Pose, or Matsyasana, stretches the hip flexors and intercostal muscles of the upper body. It can relieve muscle soreness in the spine and neck.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Fish Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"87m92","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by lying on your back. Place your arms close to your body and press your elbows and forearms into the ground to lift your upper back and chest up.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8vmt2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Slowly rest the crown of your head on the floor. If it feels that there is too much pressure on your head or neck, press into your elbows and forearms a little more, to bring more weight into your arms rather than the neck. You could also try bringing your head slightly back so that the back of the headrests against the ground. If you still feel too much pressure on your head or neck, place a blanket under your head or under your shoulder blades for support.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ii4g","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Activate the legs by pointing your toes and extending your legs away from your hips. The gaze of your eyes can look towards your nose.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"b09sk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Stay here for at least five long, deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e8tv6","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. When you are ready to come out of the pose, press your forearms into the mat and allow the head to come off the floor. Then carefully lower the back and lie back down on your back with your arms alongside the body. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:46.190Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:46.190Z","id":"959153a4-60d8-4ec7-93e1-b255089f3f68"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"fiu0b","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"6crle","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform this pose when experiencing serious headaches, insomnia, lower back pain, blood pressure issues or when you have a serious neck injury.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"384l0","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:59.516Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:10:59.516Z","id":"4459924e-a45f-4a41-8e0b-b304e46674ed"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"5najm","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• It is important that you do not feel too much pressure on your head and neck when performing this pose. You can reduce pressure by resting the back of your head instead of the crown. This also means the backbend will have a smaller arch. You could also use a rolled-up towel or blanket and place it underneath the head.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"8rme4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the backbend is too much of a challenge, you can take a rolled-up towel, blanket or cushion and place this underneath your shoulder blades.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"eqjsl","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:11:18.686Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:11:18.686Z","id":"3994f71c-bc5b-4c2b-bfe9-7e33a7a76454"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Seated Forward Bend
Alt Text: How to do Seated Forward Bend Yoga
Short Description: The Seated Forward Bend Pose or Paschimottanasana stretches and lengthens the back of the legs and torso, and strengthens the abdomen in the front of the body.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Seated Forward Bend Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"11r4l","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin sitting down with your legs stretched out in front of you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4tker","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Sit upright with your torso, while you keep the legs stretched. If your lower back is rounding a lot or if you feel the tension in your hamstrings, bend your knees until you are seated upright, or sit upon a cushion or blanket.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4vr6c","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Inhale and lengthen your spine, while bringing your lower belly and chest up, and simultaneously drawing your shoulders down and back.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"482b4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Exhale and bend forward from the front of your hips, and place your hands on either side of your legs. Keep lengthening and extending the front of your body forward.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ehhro","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Place your hands alongside your legs, shins, ankles or feet – whatever is accessible with your current flexibility. Your feet want to stay flexed and active to allow the stretch to extend towards the back of your knees and legs.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"77tst","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Stay here for a few long and deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6top4","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Avoid rounding the back too much and instead with every inhale focus on reaching your chest forward. Try moving a little deeper into the forward bend with every exhale by folding a little further forward from your hips.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"68s7v","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Keep your gaze looking out towards your feet, as you hold this position for few more deep breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"5dl6k","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Slowly come out of the pose by gently lifting the torso back into an upright sitting position.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:52:08.767Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:52:08.767Z","id":"99bd2397-e37f-4be1-a6bb-976dc0dc14a0"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bjjep","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2efhq","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• This exercise should not be performed if you have any type of back injury.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3fdsu","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Accept and respect your body’s limits and range of abilities.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cgbb1","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please contact your physician about whether this practice is good for you. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:53:16.326Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:53:16.326Z","id":"72b3236d-2401-47fe-b406-30adafe5205a"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"use a strap around the balls of your feet","decorations":[{"type":"LINK","linkData":{"link":{"url":"https://www.108yogaroad.com/yoga-poses/seated-forward-bend-with-yoga-strap","target":"BLANK","rel":{"noreferrer":true}}}},{"type":"UNDERLINE"}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":", so you can extend and lengthen the legs as much as possible, gently pulling yourself into the forward bend with your arms. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8h7rk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• You could bend the knees slightly, so it is easier to fold forward from the hips.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"q0f1b4185","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Another way to make the bend easier is by sitting on the edge of a cushion so that your hips are higher off the floor and there is more space to fold forward.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:04:35.620Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T04:04:35.620Z","id":"911648be-bd8f-4b5c-bbc3-e9ffe75a4821"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Cat Cow
Alt Text: How to do the Cat Pose Cow Pose Yoga Sequence
Short Description: Cat Pose (Marjaryasana) and Cow Pose (Bitilasana) are mostly used as a sequence done in time with the breath in yoga to warm up and bring flexibility to the spine.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cat/Cow can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6n8k41166","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Begin on the hands and knees in table top position.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"156us1169","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Make sure the hands are underneath the shoulders and the knees are underneath the hips. Untuck the toes.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1etzi1171","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Drop the belly to lift the sitting bones and the gaze to the sky, inhale (cow pose).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yxxtk1176","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Exhale, round the back like a cat, tuck the tailbone, tuck the chin, and lift the pit of the belly (cat pose).","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"x28az1178","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Repeat with the breath.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:14:09.840Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:14:09.840Z","id":"c056018b-0534-4f90-acbf-f61e5c37b199"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3v8d62735","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not do this pose if ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"it is painful to kneel","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":".","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gdcdc2739","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge, but don’t move past it. You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8wrfo2741","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:15:21.208Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:15:21.208Z","id":"90997842-2a3f-454d-aa2e-dcefa8aff943"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If it is uncomfortable on the knees, pad up the knees by folding in the sides or back end of the yoga mat, or cushion the knees using a folded blanket.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zgf4r3593","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"This sequence of poses can also be done seated and standing.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"dsj0x3596","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• ","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Try lifting one leg and bend at the knee. Press the foot up towards the sky during this modified cow pose, then bring that leg’s knee in towards the chest during this modified cat pose.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:15:58.163Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-03-17T07:15:58.163Z","id":"79a76f78-a597-43c2-a415-bfb21d7fceaa"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Camel Pose
Alt Text: How to do Camel Pose Yoga
Short Description: The Camel Pose, or Ustrasana, stretches and strengthens the ankles, knees, thighs, hips, abdomen, upper back, shoulders, and neck.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Camel Pose can be done by:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"aj44k","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start in an upright position on your knees, allowing the tops of your feet to connect into the floor.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"akam3","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Place your hands on your lower back, drawing your elbows back towards each other to open the front of your shoulders.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"co7tr","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Begin to lengthen the front of your body. Lifting your lower belly upwards and engaging the abdomen.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2gbgc","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Start to bring the gaze of your eyes up towards the ceiling. If it feels comfortable for your neck to look all the way back to the wall behind you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6i45t","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Keep reaching your hips forward, drawing your elbows back and engaging your abdomen as you stay here for a few deep and steady breaths.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cebsr","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. If you feel comfortable you can release your hand from your lower back and reach back towards your heels while arching your upper back a little more. Otherwise, stay here and come out when you’re ready. Keep grounding through your knees and tops of the feet, while hugging your inner thighs in towards each other.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bindu","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. If it feels comfortable for your neck you can let your head hang a little further back, if not keep your chin slightly tucked into the chest.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8a7t5","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Stay in this position for at least five breaths building up towards one minute. The gaze of the eyes can look towards your nose here.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"et9ln","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Come slowly out of the pose by bringing the hands back to the hips, drawing the belly in and slowly lifting your head back to a neutral position. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:18.352Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:18.352Z","id":"b1ff88b8-7d42-4adb-89ed-02c2d18f7794"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3mg3l","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"76on2","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Be careful attempting this pose if you have lower back pain. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"75cje","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Always listen to your body.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9fqia","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• When uncertain if this position is beneficial for you, please consult your physician about whether this practice is good for you.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:38.263Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:38.263Z","id":"83315fd5-f7c5-4a6e-9af4-cb1162af0b8d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3lqni","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are new to this position it is a good idea to not bend too far. Just stay in the position where your hands are on the lower back and keep breathing deep and steady.  • You can also tuck your toes under, so the heels are higher off the floor and easier to reach with your hands.  ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"87ltk","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you have sensitive knees you can place a blanket under your knees.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:55.250Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-11-28T07:02:55.250Z","id":"d9f66bd3-24e7-4366-bf29-86109a95ab57"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: One-Legged Frog Pose with Yoga Strap
Alt Text: How to do One-Legged Frog Pose with a Yoga Strap
Short Description: The One-Legged Frog Pose, or Eka Pada Bhekasana, with Yoga strap, stretches the quadriceps and back. Use of the Yoga strap improves access to this pose.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The One-Legged Frog Pose with Yoga strap can be done by:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"t12hj247920","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"1. Start by lying on your belly.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hdqjb247922","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"2. Come on to your elbows.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mdqp6247924","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"3. Bend your right leg and reach behind to loop the Yoga strap around the top of the foot with right hand.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2h263247926","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"4. Left forearm is flat on the mat with the elbow underneath the shoulder.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bxzp8247928","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"5. Hold the strap in the right hand and position your right hand so that your thumb is facing away from you. The strap comes over the right shoulder.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4etys247930","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"6. Slowly pull on the strap to draw the foot towards the backside and stretch the thigh.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zbu2x247932","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"7. Keep your torso straight.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bcqsm247934","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"8. Hold pose for several breaths, deepening the stretch as you are able.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ieanj247936","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"9. Repeat with the left leg.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:40.010Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:27:40.010Z","id":"f9e00ec0-54f1-470d-8a2f-1f072bf7e2d1"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pcolx247942","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Read the following cautions to stay safe:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8gbpf247945","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Do not perform the bend of this pose if you have a back injury. Instead, place the left forearm parallel with the front of the mat and rest the forehead on the left forearm. Lengthen the strap with the arm next to the body instead of over the shoulder. This is also useful to try if you have a shoulder injury.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a1awa247948","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• Never push too far in a pose. Find your edge","decorations":[]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":", but don't move past it","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":". You should feel the pose working in the body, but still be able to breathe deeply and find some ease in the pose.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"2uqd9247951","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If you are concerned about anything with this pose, please consult a physician about whether this practice is good for you.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:11:21.563Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-12T03:11:21.563Z","id":"508d8a07-1b04-4555-a6b0-483fc0ef7446"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0},"style":{},"id":"n7u4l247956","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"• If the stretch of the back or shoulder is too strenuous, try the above option detailed under ‘Cautions’.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"","foreground":""}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:28:22.309Z","updatedTimestamp":"2022-12-05T02:28:22.309Z","id":"d683ccab-6810-4e1d-8e85-e3cefc77b846"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Upward-Facing Dog
Alt Text: How to do Upward-Facing Dog
Short Description: Upward Dog is a heart-opening yoga pose that involves lifting the chest while the hands and feet press into the ground. It improves posture and strengthens the back and core.
Notes: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Upward Dog can be done by:","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"rgb(247, 247, 248)","foreground":"rgb(55, 65, 81)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"1hh4n74886","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"f06f374887","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"eu4py74888","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Start by lying flat on your belly with your legs extended and the tops of your feet pressing into the mat.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"ycx5374890","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"571u174891","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Place your hands on the ground, directly under your shoulders, with your fingers spread wide and pointing forward.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"fmdtf74893","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wzjkp74894","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Press down firmly through your hands and the tops of your feet, engaging your core muscles.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"lhbh374896","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"anzii74897","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Inhale deeply and begin to straighten your arms, lifting your chest and upper body off the mat. Keep your hips and legs grounded.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"bxl6x74899","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"qin0074900","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Roll your shoulders back and down, opening your chest and lifting your heart towards the ceiling.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"zs6j174902","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gixfy74903","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Look straight ahead or slightly upward, keeping your neck in line with your spine.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"uvq5g74905","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"s9ezq74906","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Ensure your elbows are slightly bent, and avoid locking them to prevent strain on the joints.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"j7nxp74908","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"hz7i074909","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Press firmly through your palms and the tops of your feet, engaging your thighs and buttocks for support.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"7r1xe74911","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"rk0m374912","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Hold the pose for a few breaths, maintaining a gentle stretch in your spine and front body.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"lxjoo74914","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5qswj74915","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To release the pose, exhale and slowly lower your chest back down to the mat.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"m831374917","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"r7ddn74937","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Benefits:","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"ORDERED_LIST","id":"wvpmz74919","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"94huf74920","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gu6ou74921","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Strengthens the back, shoulders, and arms.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"rlp9p74923","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ynrmz74924","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Stretches and opens the chest and front body, promoting better posture and respiratory capacity.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}}]}],"orderedListData":{"indentation":0}}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:53:04.127Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:53:04.127Z","id":"7f69452e-8fb7-4d9a-9c4c-03f1e61fab4d"},"documentStyle":{}}
Cautions: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"While Upward Dog (Urdhva Mukha Svanasana) can be a beneficial pose for many, there are some cautions and contraindications to be aware of:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"85w0x75816","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"shbe375817","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"f2nph75745","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wrist Pain or Injury: If you have existing wrist pain or injury, be mindful while performing Upward Dog, and consider using yoga props like blocks to alleviate pressure on the wrists.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"8hnsi75819","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"41tz675748","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lower Back Issues: Individuals with lower back problems should exercise caution in this pose. To avoid strain, engage the core muscles and focus on lifting the chest rather than arching the lower back excessively.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"cmac775821","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jqfue75751","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pregnancy: Pregnant women should modify the pose by performing Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana) instead, as Upward Dog's deep backbend may not be suitable during pregnancy.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"x2cfl75823","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"q5yxn75754","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Recent Abdominal Surgery: People who have undergone recent abdominal surgery should avoid deep backbends like Upward Dog until they have fully healed.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"d66c775825","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pfwuq75760","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: If you suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome, avoid putting excessive weight on your hands in this pose, as it may exacerbate the condition.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"xo2f175827","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pqsvp75763","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Spinal Injury: Individuals with severe spinal injuries or conditions should avoid this pose, as the deep backbend can put additional stress on the spine.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"hfpx175829","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"579g875766","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wrist, Arm, or Shoulder Injury: If you have any injuries to your wrists, arms, or shoulders, it's best to avoid Upward Dog until the injuries have healed.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"pbkni75831","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"z6hca75769","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"High Blood Pressure: Upward Dog can increase blood flow to the head and may not be suitable for those with uncontrolled high blood pressure.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7xcaz75771","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vdrst75813","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Always consult with a qualified yoga instructor or healthcare professional if you have any pre-existing conditions or concerns before attempting Upward Dog or any other yoga poses. They can provide personalized guidance and modifications to ensure your practice is safe and beneficial.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:54:46.089Z","updatedTimestamp":"2023-07-24T08:54:46.089Z","id":"55982c9d-216e-4db0-b29b-75d9529136d6"},"documentStyle":{}}
Options: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"If you have limitations or find Upward Dog challenging, there are several options and alternatives you can explore to modify the pose or find a variation that suits your needs:","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"BULLETED_LIST","id":"4ftnp76745","nodes":[{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"q189p76721","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"y6jp276722","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana): Cobra Pose is a gentler backbend that can be a suitable alternative for those with wrist issues or limited back flexibility. Instead of straightening your arms, keep your forearms on the ground and lift your chest, using your back muscles.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"f7ew276724","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"x8euy76725","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Sphinx Pose: Sphinx Pose is another accessible alternative to Upward Dog. Lie on your belly with your elbows under your shoulders and forearms flat on the mat. Lift your chest, keeping your hips and thighs on the ground, and look forward.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"gssw376727","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"27ggp76728","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Baby Cobra Pose: If Cobra Pose is still too intense, you can try Baby Cobra. From a prone position, gently lift your chest off the mat using your hands and a light engagement of your back muscles. Keep your elbows bent and close to your sides.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"zgmbn76730","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"htc4d76731","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Modified Upward Dog: To reduce strain on the wrists, place your fists or forearms on the mat instead of your palms. This modification can also be helpful for individuals with wrist pain or injury.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"smwaz76733","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7h87676734","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Wall-Assisted Upward Dog: Stand facing a wall and place your hands on the wall at shoulder height. Step back a little and lean into the wall, gently arching your back and lifting your chest. This variation can be helpful for those with limited wrist mobility or strength.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"sjc0p76736","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"uay5n76737","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Upward Dog with Props: Use yoga blocks or bolsters under your hands to elevate the height and reduce the bend in your wrists. This can be beneficial for individuals with wrist discomfort.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]},{"type":"LIST_ITEM","id":"tmryl76739","nodes":[{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"sksnv76740","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Upward Dog with Knees Down: Perform Upward Dog with your knees on the mat instead of your feet. This modification can be helpful for beginners or individuals with lower back sensitivity.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}]}],"bulletedListData":{"indentation":0}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vftbz76742","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7b85p76762","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Remember, it's essential to listen to your body and practice within your comfort zone.
